reviewText:
The Good
Gorgeous environments.
They've built a whole language for the game which helps immerse you in the new setting.
Initially fun mechanics.
The game runs very well.
The movement and base combat systems generally feel polished.
Talented voice actors.
The Bad
Recycled wildlife species with different skins".
Recycled word quests and events.
Recycled talent trees with the exception of a few new abilities.
The world feels empty of things to do
date:
walking from place to place feels like a chore.
Beastmaster mechanics become repetitive and eventually you become extremely overpowered making clearing outposts extremely dull and unsatisfying. Combat begins to feel like a chore.
Unsatisfying story with anti-climactic events.
New mechanics such as the "cold" meter feel underdeveloped and superfluous.
Instead of being filled with meaningful content
recommended:
the world is filled with meaningless collectibles and recycled side missions.
Far too many fetch quests in the main story line. The game starts to feel like a slog.
Overall thoughts
From an audio/visual standpoint

reviewText:
In an age where people compare a game to how they liked another game, yeah I understand that this game probably isn't the best. However if I judge this game based on how I enjoy the game, this is a great game.

I watch all my tv with subtitles, so hearing the odd language and reading the subtitles isn't a big deal for me. I kind of enjoy it to be honest. I laugh all the time at how they structure their sentences and the phrases they use don't feel genuin for the time period, but it is still funny and enjoyable.

I keep all my drivers on my pc up to date, and have a fairly expensive build. As a result I believe this is why I dont have problems running the game; and maybe ubisoft loves me. It is kind of annoying that you buy this through steam but you launch with steam, then ubisoft.

Gameplay feels different from the games I have been playing lately. Trying to take over an outpost while being undetected I feel like I could do many different methods and be successful. If I want to be hidden the whole time, I have a tactic for that. If I wanted to rush through it I have a tactic to do that as well. Theres much more on the gameplay aspect of this game that has been enjoyable that I just don't have the time to type it all here.

10 hours into the game and I am only 22% through this game, only having 2 major quests completed, and constantly having things to do. So far its been fun, and I had some crazy moments that made me laugh. Cannot wait to play through more of this game.

If you were able to read through this entire thing you are great. If this review was helpful in your decision to buy the game let me know. If however, no matter the positive reviews you still dont decide to buy this game, I hope you enjoy the next game you get.

reviewText:
Turn off:
all auto assists, hud elements,the minimap,

dont tag enemies, dont use the owl, do not use hunter vision, do not fast travel, dont chase every little icon on the map, try not using the map and navigating like a caveman, put the difficulty up to where you feel its a little too hard to really get you feeling vulnerable.

It will feel strange at first. But trust me, something wonderfull will happen and might change the way you approach open world games in the future.

Immerse yourself in this wonderfully crafted universe and you have got yourself a great game. Otherwise you will find yourself staring at your minimap, and fast travelling from icon to icon doing pointless tasks, ticking every little box untill you reach 100% completion.

Worth it, but wish the developers had the guts to try something different. I am just glad I found a way to make this experience my own.

reviewText:
Too short to be a proper game, and too long to be just DLC, Far Cry Primal falls somewhere in between. Far Cry Primal is a copy and pasted Far Cry 4, some things have changed, but it's not enough to be worth the price it's being currently sold at. Being set in the stone age, the weapons that you have are vastly different and more primative from the other games in the series (obviously), but there is nothing good about this, the bows I found were too weak to be useful, I ended up throwing spears instead, and the melee weapons (there are 3, club two handed club, and spear) felt dreadful. The melee combat had not been developed at all since the past games, which isn't a good idea because in the other games you do not rely so heavily on using melee. On the standard mode, normal, this game was way too easy, I rarely used the owl to scout when I discovered I could simply charge in with a spear and spam left click.

The only language spoken in the game is a mix of made up words with a Proto-Indo-European structure, this was an issue as it meant that it was near impossible to have a real connection with any of the characters, by the end of the game I could remember basically only the main characters name as the other characters didn't mean much to me, their stories felt pointless and were there just to make the game time longer. I didn't feel like I was doing anything for a reason, I'd go to a place and kill some people and burn some stuff, with no real care as to why. The main story was also short and uneventful, spoilers but there aren't really any twists during the entire game, you go to a place, kill some person and it's gg.

The main antagonist of the game was no where near as interesting as the other Far Cry game's baddies, I felt no emotions towards him and never really wanted to kill him because he hadn't really done anything, he comes to your village in one scene and burns like a hut or two and suddenly he's the sole base of the games story.

Overall running around in 10,000 B.C was fairly enjoyable, but it felt so pointless, easy and I was never really immersed in the world, at the current price I would strongly advise against buying Far Cry Primal, if you still want it that badly then I'd just wait for it's price to drop massivley because only then would it be close to being worth a buy.

reviewText:
Three things right off the bat because I see SO many negative reviews based on such silly stuff.

1) If you're giving this game a negative review because you've played the other Far Cry games and you don't think it's up to par, I'd like to extend my deepest sympathies to you, that you tried something different and judged it on an already-existing standard. I'd like to point out that this wasn't supposed to be a direct copy of the other Far Cry games, whilst still being a Far Cry game. However out of all the reviews I see, these 'experts' are playing the game on normal and complaining about it being 'too easy'. I'm running around on expert mode having the time of my life and feeling some very REAL fear when confronted by a Sabretooth. A big part of Far Cry is immersion. Game is too easy? Up the difficulty. It's not neuroscience. If you're not feeling hunted when you're running around at night, you're not playing on a hard enough difficulty. Don't give a bad review because you didn't decide to challenge yourself.

2) People keep complaining that the melee system is flawed. Why? Because there aren't brutal melee finishers for every weapon? Last time I checked if you got into a brawl with 3 guys with a club it's not going to be a moment of finesse. It's gonna be a moment of blind rage-induced swinging hoping to hit their faces. The same is true for the spear. If I stab someone in the face or the throat it counts as a 'headshot' and is an instant fatality. That is the sort of accuracy of a spear. You're trying to tell me we should be able to swing it around like a quarterstaff? Far Cry isn't known for prompted cinematic kill moves other than silent melee kills with most weapons. Why did you expect anything other than the very basic idea of an amateur swinging a stick? You're a caveman. Not a professional assassin.

3) Complaining about the fact that they went through the trouble to include genuine proto-european dialect, or that the game is too short. I reiterate, a big part of Far Cry is immersion. If you're not paying attention to the script, the emotion in their voices, or the storyline, and then you complain about not enjoying it, it doesn't sound like a problem with the game. That sounds like a problem with you paying attention. When it comes to timeframe, I'm 33.3 hrs into the game right now, and due to difficulty level (died probably 14 times trying to kill Dah) and how I genuinely enjoy hunting in this game, I've got plenty of collectibles and side quests left, and several story and character missions.

All in all, I'm not trying to bash anyone for their review because everyone has their own opinion. However I felt that this game was very harshly judged and mostly so because of the preceding games. People either expected something completely different or relatively the same. The weird balance in between seems to have some people upset, but did any of you really expect Far Cry to evolve as a series without some trail and error? Considering this is their first foray into any other era than modern, I'd say they did pretty damn good.

8/10 For a decent story about the brutality of this time period.
9/10 For appearances, the game is just plain pretty on high settings! Spent probably over an hour of gameplay just admiring certain views!
9/10 for performance. From being attacked by Dholes at any moment to wondering if that growl from a Cave Lion was near or far, the game definitely gives the impression of a nonstop fight for survival.

reviewText: I was really scared away from this game by all the bad reviews and luckily I got it anyway.The game is beautiful first and foremost. I get a steady 50 fps on my less than stellar PC. I've read a lot of reviews that say the map is identical to Far Cry 4. This is simply false. I've seen the meme that outlines their similar structure but this map loooks nothing like the Far Cry 4. Someone had the audacity to claim there is bad character development in this game. I fell in love with the characters in this game. Without speaking a single word of english (which is usually a deal breaker for me but they did a great job with language in this game) the characters are very likeable and fun. There is a lot of humor in the characters interactions as well. People obsess over recycled" this and that but at the end of the day it's a damn series. Of course there will be carry-over from previous games (that you presumeably liked since you're playing the follow up) but that doesn't mean they didn't spend time on the important things like STORY and characters."

reviewText:
I admit it: I'm a huge fan of Open World Collectathons.

While these types of games have now become pretty formulaic, some still try to do something new, and Far Cry: Primal is one of them.

No sniper rifles, C4, tanks or revolvers. Only your trusty stone axe, the double arrow bow, bee grenades and and an owl that drops LSD on your enemies.

This is 10,000 BC where you get to ride saber tigers, eat raw meat like there is no tomorrow, have acid trips where you shoot the moon with your bow and your hardest animal enemy is that damn badger once again.

Lots of different side quests that pop up all the time, some great cave platform puzzles, beautiful graphics and a stone age grappling hook makes this one of my favourite Ubisoft open world games of all time.

reviewText:
So you take Far Cry 4 and remove fire arms, all kind of vehicles, helicopter, wingsuit, etc., remove the explosive arrows, turn elephants into mammoths, replace radio towers with bonfires, binoculars with an owl... And wait.. Wasn't there one more thing that was fun in Far Cry 4? Ah yea of course! The co-op. That got removed as well.

The spear animation is ridiculous just as most of the melee fight animations. It's just poking! And enemies don't even have wounds where you poked them. So actually you're just clicking your mouse, there is no real fight system. There are Takedowns but we've seen them already haven't we?

The hunter vision looks like witcher senses from The Witcher.

The pet system... That could have been something new and nice but what they did is, they let you tame animals (in the blink of a keystroke), and afterwards you can press G so they attack or ALT so they stay. You can also pet them. That actually is all the pet system" does. Even the early access ARK let's you do more with your "pets". Also taming animals makes more sense in ARK.

Main missions play like side missions. Why? Because all you get to do is going somewhere (which takes awfully long because you don't have any vehicles of course) and gather some stuff. That's it. Sometimes it's not gathering stuff but taming some animal.

There actually is no other activity to do in Primal other than taming animals
recommended:
gathering resources and ambushing/capturing bonfires. Crafting is so basic compared to other games that it can't be considered a part of the gameplay. You just collect resources and click menus so you can finally carry around more stuff or what ever you upgrade.


Is there anything positive about this game? The graphics look better than Far Cry 4. You could even say it looks great. But then again

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to this game, but had nothing but problems. Started with Error Code 88500014, fixed this by adding an exception in my firewall. Game finally loaded and hung beofre it started. After 4-5 hours messing around trying to get it to work, I gave up.

Contacted Ubisoft via thier support, forum, twitter and Steam and didn't recieve one single response. So I uninstalled the game.

I pre-ordered Far Cry: Primal along with The Division. After many problems with the Division Beta (which is not ready for release in a weeks time) and  now having problems with Primal, I have requested and been granted a refund for both products.

As mentioned, with The Division being released in 7days, It's nowhere near ready. Far Cry: Primal is a testiment as to what to look forward to. Both of these Ubisoft titles are not ready for release (and I mean nowhere near ready) and it makes me wary of ever buying any Ubisoft game again.

I know people say don't pre-order, but usually you get extra stuff and that's what I want out of a game, but in the end, the developers should have a working game instead of something riddled with bugs and errors on Zero Day!

Totally dissapointing.

Edit: For those of you trying to be clever by offering words of wisdom about pre-ordering, when you buy a brand new shiny car, you mostly have to pre-order it (though most of you probably aren’t old enough to shave, let alone drive), same goes with food. Buy a tin of beans for next week’s dinner, and yes, you have just pre-ordered and own a tin of beans. Opening the beans, you find the contents have turned bad or some form of dead, rotting insect is floating in the beany goodness. You'd be pretty miffed that your favorite beans are not what they should have been and you complain or want a refund. The point, when you pay for a new product, you want it to be working 100%. We all pre-order something. But If I decide too, that's my business and my choice and it's nothing to do with you. I can change my mind at any point about pre-ordering, but being a sad, pathetic little comment troll and a complete m o r o n is something you will have to live with for the rest of your life.

reviewText: It's not awful.  There's a lot of polish here in terms of the animations and open world mechanics but that's kinda where it stops.  Far Cry: Primal feels like a really solid foundation for a superb survival game but utterly fails to capitalise.  There are no real driving mechanics governing the necessary acquisition of food, water or shelter, and only a token gesture at warmth.  Nor is there any sense of mortal peril.  If you are severely wounded after a tough fight, you can heal to full health in a matter of seconds.  Even if you die there are no real consequences; only the minor inconvenience of respawning nearby.  It’s not that it tries to deliver a survival game and comes up short, it just doesn’t appear to make any attempt to do so; leaving the player with a beautiful environment but an empty experience.

reviewText: I don't understand the mixed reviews. It was different and I wasn't sure I really liked it at first. Then I just kept playing it and found out I really like it. I like it. I recommend it.

reviewText: I know I'm gonna get hate for this but Far Cry Primal is one of my favorite games ever.  Ever since I was 3 I've fantasized about being a caveman in the Ice Age era hunting mammoths and taming wild beasts.  This game is the closest I'm ever going to get to that fantasy and I'm loving it.  The gameplay is what you expect from Far Cry, in other words, it sublime.  THe melee combat feels brutal and satisfying and getting headshots with the bow and arrow is so much fun!  It might look it's not an innovate game but it is incredibly innovative as a concept for a game.  I know a lot of people had problems with crashes but I haven't had thosse issues and I think Ubisoft patched the game because I'm not hearing about crashes anymore.  I implore you, give Far Cry Primal a go because it could end up being one of your favorite games of 2016.

reviewText:
I've seen a lot of negative reviews for this game. Not Far Cry enough? I beg to differ. You're still running around a lush open world, murdering your enemies like a righteous badass; it just so happens that your living in 10,000 BC this time around. So, no massive arsenal of machine guns and rocket launchers and the like. Instead you're rocking (heh heh puns) a more primitive arsenal. Your spear is your best friend in the wilds, functioning both as a face-jabber and a long range projectile. You've also got clubs for more personal encounters (which can also be thrown) and of course, a trusty bow. Any weapon you throw can be retrieved, plus you can craft more weapons on the go - which means foraging for resources and supplies is now an important part of your life.

Oh yeah, you can also tame wild beasts, which is good since pretty much everything wants to kill you and make you its lunch. Once tamed, said beast becomes sort of like a 'familiar' in the sense that you can call and dismiss it at will. There is a pretty good variety of beasts to tame and each has its own specialties and abilities. Plus, you've got your very own spirit animal - the trusty owl which can be used to scout the surrounding area, mark enemies, attack from above and even drop bombs on unsuspecting foes.

Seriously... what's not to love? If you're a Far Cry fan I implore you to at least give it a chance. Hell, even if you've never played a Far Cry game in your life I still recommend you give it a go!

reviewText:
Yeah......the game honestly...feels a bit primitive. For 60 bucks? and 5 bucks more you get a horrible mammoth mission, a mammoth with no legs that floats around and can't stop gliding here and there. The graphics for a 2016 game....well, the scenery is nice, can't complain there. However, it would have been much nicer if it had better textures, very low res foliage. The environment is so much fun to play in however. Can't stop looking at the vistas....at the same time, can't stop how badly the vistas' View Of Distance are. When you climb the mountain....the grass, animals, people and smoke all disappear, and the mountains are really not all that high.

With this game, every good point has a bad point, and bad point with a good point. I can't stop playing, and yet at the same time can't help but notice there are such few side missions. Story wise.....I don't know remember anyone except for Sayla and Takkhar(Takkar, depending on region of game). Playing with bow and arrow sure makes the game more challenging, having to wip out the tiny club or big club in split second before you get your head bashed in, AWESOME. Playing with fire (however not new as this is the same thing with every farcry series) still AWESOME. I loved the fact that animals are scared of certain beasts and fire. But, when you traverse the land of Oros, you seem to come across your people, Udam, predators and prey.....all in the same 10 meters of eachother...every 2 minutes( yes, I actually timed it). There is no peaceful free-roam really, every step you take, you come across an enemy, or enemies attacking my people, or enemies attacking prey, which in turn then for some reason attack both attack me for some reason (Not having Facebook in Oros at that time and being the Beast Master, they sure know how to spot me.....animals and enemies both)

All in all, this is an addon for farcry 4, same engine with same tactics. However fallout 4 was same engine as Skyrim, look at the difference there! So, there is no excuse as to why the graphics have not been maxed....specially for 60 bucks. No NVIDIA hair effects? really? And of course, no mod support, so we can't make the game look or feel better even if we wanted to. I'll have to give it 50/50....which Unfortunately means....thumbs down. Not worth 60 bucks, however it is worth playing if you have the money to waste.

reviewText:
+++ Graphically, it sets a new parameter, replacing Crysis 3 as the most beautiful game ever made. The ambience of Oros alone makes it worth buying the game.
+++ As for the gameplay, Primal reproduces the great formula of FC 3 and 3.5 (4); the movimentation and the aim are very fluid as well as the adaptation for more focus on hand to hand combat is very nice.
+ The story is ok. Not bad but not as engaging as we saw on FC 3.
+++ Ubi made a awesome job with the soundtrack.
+++ The game is a lot of fun if you play it at least on hard difficulty; that way, you really need to think about your approach on the main missions and when capturing advanced posts. Also, Primal has a good replayability value.
- The PC port definetly could be better. The game does not take advantage of multi-core processors. I had some small fps drops with a GTX 970 and i5 4590 (not fully maxed out [shadows only on high] 'n' playin' @ 1080p) and alt-tabbing the game makes it unplayable. Altough you can eliminate this problem by resetting the processor affinity values in the task manager, the procedement has to be made everytime you launch the game, which is a little annoying.

Overall, this FPS with tiny RPG elements is a marvelous game.

9/10

reviewText:
As an anthropologist this game is pure joy. I just wish one of the parts of the mechanics was to unlock flint-knapping skills. I also wish you could cave paint, though I am glad it plays a small part in the game.

Totally a Far Cry game. Outposts, side quests, collectable hunts, crafting. If you are tired of that move on. If you like that it is here.

There is no over the top Vaas-like villain here, and for some that is clearly disappointing. I could care less. I for one don't play open world games for the story, I play for the world interactions. I guess if you don't read books then you may want more story here. For myself I find the narrative pieces and missions often the most frustrating parts of this whole genre.

In this game the crafting is more integrated than ever before. The materials hunt is meaningful to the gameplay and you use it to replenish your weapons and supplies to the very end of the game.

It is not a caveman sim. It is a Beast-master fable set in a late ice age world. The animal control is key part of the tactics of the game and serve to allow some of the mayhem type of action that was so much fun in FC3 and FC4.

The map textures are familiar. The way you move around on foot is familiar (I never drove that much in the FC games after FC2). Many say the map is reused from FC4, but I never once felt like I was in that map. It is a Far Cry map to be sure, but it still felt fresh to me.

I don't regret a single cent that I spent on this. This is one of the first Ubi-soft games that I actually have managed to get all of the achievements and pick up all of the collectables and enjoyed the process from beginning to end. I love it.

Totally fun.

reviewText:
Seeing so many negative reviews, I had to contribute something positive despite my minimal playtime. I apologize if this review is lacking, as it is my first. Long story short, it's a Far Cry game. It has stealth kills, basic crafting, animal hunting, karma events, outposts, collectibles, all the bare bones stuff that has become the basis of the Far Cry series. That's where most people will complain, but Primal is more than it's skeleton.

Good Stuff
- Great setting. Running through the environment is awesome.
- Language is pretty cool, though I've had a few laughs at how it sounds sometimes (Think male Twi'lek from KOTOR. You know the one).
- Limited base building. You can't choose where it goes, but I like seeing the village being built up over time.

Hit or Miss
- Taming system is basic, but there are plenty of animal choices.
- Melee is simple, but fun.

Bad Stuff
- Open world elements are the usual Far Cry filler.

Without guns, the pace of combat has changed quite a bit. Sure, Jason/Ajay could charge someone swinging a sword wildly, but in Primal you're far less likely to get suckerpunched and shot in the face. The melee combat is simple, but effective. I haven't had this much fun bashing things in an FPS since Bioshock and Half-Life.

The taming system is about as primitive as it gets, throw meat and press the button. I dislike this, but beating a sabretooth tiger halfway unconscious with a club while it tears you limb from limb probably isn't as fun as it sounds in my head. We can't all be Drago Bludvist, I guess. The animals themselves are fairly varied, with different stats and abilities between the species. It's pretty fun comboing them together - start attacking from stealth with your leopard, then call on your lion/tiger/bear (oh my) to finish them off in open combat.

The major complaint about Primal is going to be that it's just more of the same. And I suppose in a way it is, but if that's the attitude you take then you'll miss the forest for the trees.

reviewText:
A brutally honest review of Far Cry: Primal, played on Expert difficulty, by a HUGE fan of the Far Cry series.
-----

Far Cry: Primal really makes you feel like you're a part of our ancient history. The immersion is amazing and genuinely feels like you're a terrified, tasty piece of meat, walking around carrying a stick. ..Until you become a near-god, 24~hrs into the game and find yourself thinking about all the other games available for the sticker price of $60ish.

[tl;dr] - This is a pass / wait until a discount comes out. Ignore the hype..

-----
Cons
*Missions: My biggest complaint is the lack of auto-added minimap waypoints, once you've begun a mission. Yet the game will allow you to set a way point on the other side of the map, and that shows on your minimap. But if you accept a mission and the objective is out of your viewing range, the new mission icon on your world-map, will be the exact same size shape and color as all the other missions strewn all over. Good luck finding it.

*Story: What story? Caveman loses tribe. Caveman saves idiots, grows a village. TA DA. >.>

*Enemies: Remember the drunk, Molotov tossing idiots in Far Cry 3? They're reskinned in 2 flavors. All the other enemies are exactly the same, in reguards to their mechanics, and just as repetitious and boring. /Copy Far Cry 3, retexture, change dialog, print.

*Skills/Leveling/Experience: I'm 40% in and nearly all of my Skill are maxed already. I'll be capped by 50% completion. The XP comes way too fast and far too easily. Accelerating the processes is the bonus XP to level, for completing missions and growing the population! YAY! Cap everything in 60 Hrs!

*Taming: I was hoping this would involve some mini-game, requiring skill and finesse, to eventually tame a new catagory of beasts. Nope. Might as well be point-click-tamed. And it ALWAYS succeeds. I have every beast tamed that doesn't require a special mission (and only because I'm saving them).

*Beasts: Your pet died? Mk. Open a menu and click the icon. Good as new. No wait time, and no punishment for letting your pet bleed-out.

*Crafting: The resource nodes are so abundant and easy to acquire, that you'll end up capped in the first 3 hours. You'll stay that way for the majority of the game, only dropping below cap as the Skills you select, unlock crafting options.

*Survivability/Difficulty: I am now Caveman-Superman. It took 8-12hrs to become fearless. And at 25~ I will now charge head on at any creature or enemy and poke them with a sharpened stick, knowing full well that they will collapse long before I do. Rinse-Repeat.

*FIRE: ...don't use it. Seriously. Its like turning on God-Mode and lawl-clipping your way through the game. Everything pee's their pants, panics and get's 1-shot. (metaphorically)

-----
Pros
*Survivability/Difficulty: You will die, a LOT.. for 12 hours; Until you get used to the aiming / controls and learn the sounds of animals nearby. Then, see above about the same subject. But for 12~ish hours, you will ♥♥♥♥ yourself every time you're charged by anything. And you WILL get eaten / mauled / trampled / gored and set on fire. Its terrifying, like Doom 3, all over again.

*Vehicles: I won't go into details, as I found out about this aspect only by immersion, but its the best feature of the game. Nothing beats hauling ♥♥♥ at cheetah speeds, at night, through the ancient forests.

*Language: The Tribes all speak different dialects of a Proto-Indo-European ancestor language that Linguistic Historians reconstructed and developed specifically for FC:P. The immersion it provides is heightened some-what by the lack of subtitles during open-world encounters.

-----
If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to comment. I will answer what I can in a generic form, as to not spoil your gaming experience. Nothing pisses me off more than spoilers to a game/movie I'm VERY excited about.

reviewText:
Having played Farcry 3 and 4 for ~50hrs each, I knew what I was going to get coming into this game - Farcry 3 with 10,000 BC skins and items/weapons etc. And that is exactly what you get. I've enjoyed the story so far, it's not nearly as good as Farcry 3 (or 4), but it is an enjoyable game, especially if you loved the previous ones.

Looks gorgeous on my PC at around 70fps @ 1440p (i7-2600k @ 4.6ghz, 16gb ram, GTX970 SLI) but owing to it's console base, not nearly as good looking as say a modded skyrim which runs about the same. Best part is spending some time in the world running around with the bow (and spear) like I did in the previous games - simple pleasures I guess.

Pros/cons;

+ Open world Farcry 3/4 'reskin' with new location/items etc
+ Looks good and is immersive as you run around the world, especially at night
+ Crafting system
+ Addition of beasts
+ Some of the NPC characters are a bit of fun

- Story not as engaging as the previous 2 Farcry games
- Repetitive (particularly capturing bases and free/save quests)
- Should be better optimised
- No HD textures

Overall, like most games nowadays unless you're a huge fan of the franchise I don't see it being worth full price. If you liked Farcry 3 or 4, wait until it is on sale and grab it for 30-50% off and enjoy 30+hrs in the world.

reviewText:
Personally for me - So close to a 10/10

If you love exploring and finding collectibles with a combination of stone-age open world survival without minding story-rich content then this game is pretty much perfect to spend your time in.

Far Cry Primal is a glimpse into the past that takes the player in a hypothetical setting somewhere in the middle Europe of around 10000 BC. You play as a character who while surviving in the wild finds out that he has the ability to tame wild carnivores and use them as allies in order to achieve the only goal that mattered at that time. Survival at its best and making sure that your tribe survives.

The aim of the game is to help you emerge in a world that 3 tribes coexist, each trying to claim their own land and right to hunt, live and evolve. Your clan, the Wenja, a group of people who are spread all over the land and which you need to help survive and form a safe community. The Izila, a group of people who seem to be more evolved, are aware of how to use resources like fire and materials in order to build communities and temples and have a basic form of civilization. And the Udam, a group of people that seem to be the last remains of the kind of Homo Erectus (a species that ironically has stoped existing ever since the 70000BC but is set in the game in order to spice things up) and are at the edge of extinction.

The game offers a very interesting set of gameplay features and skills. You can craft some basic types of weapons at start and then either by evolving your crafting skills (for example finding a unique type of volcano rock to make knives out of) or by exploring(for example through the quests you will find a better type of bow) you get to have upgraded forms of these items. All your items can be crafted with materials you need to find. From gathering wood and rocks to meat and bones and special animal skins (thankfully you can set the gathering animation off). You can use nature to your benefit now and this matters a lot. You can combine strategies using your tamed animals, the element of fire, sneak attacks and your weapons in order to achieve your goals.

Graphics are amazing. I didn’t mind a few FPS drops now and then, im not going to pretend I care for a drop from 60FPS to 40FPS, things were always still smooth while set on Ultra specs. Sound and environmental design is AMAZING. Exploration is very fun and satisfying. The map size is decent, though the shape is similar to that of Far Cry 4’s but something I didn’t really mind at all because the whole design and nature settings is unique. Voice acting was nice, eventhough the languages in the game are completely made up, I find it interesting when voice actors manage to pass feelings, ideas and character to you without making any sense in words, everything was based on the perfect balance between voice and face expressions.

The game as a new release has some bugs. I missed a Uplay achievement from an action I already completed. There is a type of collectible that when found doesn’t let you interact with it. The AI of people of your clan is not so smart during missions that you have to help them. They might get on the way, get hurt, and then see you as an enemy, which is annoying since every single person you save becomes a +1 member on your growing community – a village which you will spend time and materials to help build and even upgrade.

Now many complain for this game that it is a reskin of farcry 3 and 4. That the map is the same with FC4. That is has no story. The fact is that the trailers provided and the spoiler-free opinions expressed before this was available on PC had me knowing almost exactly where I was stepping in. Hard Core Far Cry fans got something that was not what Far Cry meant to them until now. But you know what the game by itself is great. I loved this game a pretty damn lot. Only couple of things i mind is that I wish this game had a longer cmpaign and that that it's too bad it hasn’t a co-op option, like going hunting with a friend, or having a game mode with special co-op missions. That would be sweet (if done right).

All in all, I loved this game. It left me satisfied. It had enough content to leave me happy. There were some fun moments. And there were some funny moments too. I do recommend this game but I kinda wish there was a bit more into this making it worthy to spend at least 10 or 20 more hours in it. DLCs will cost money which makes me also wish this was a 50 buck title and not a 60.

It’s a 8/10 with potential of 9/10 if some fixes take place soon.
It’s nice, its beautiful, its enjoyable but a bit expensive for what it offers.

reviewText:
Feels like a cut down version of Far Cry 4, there are only 3 real weapon types and they don't feel that satisfying. (the spear in particular when used as a melee attack rather than thrown, the animation is literally instapoke instapoke jabbing into character models without any real weight to it.)

I know the setting means I can't have guns and trucks and mini helicopters, but once I have experienced that and then go to play a game that essentially feels the same, (albeit with the promise of taming the animals that pillaged me raw initially and then having them pillage my enemies instead) I can't help constantly thinking about how much more fun Far Cry 4 is with guns, Kyrat radio and shouting Indians.

This game is probably entertaining enough to finish, but I'm not going to find out until it's on sale sometime, if you haven't played Far Cry 4 and you are considering buying this, I strongly recommend paying less money and having more fun by purchasing FC4.

This game does not make sense at full price, praise Gaben and praise Steam refunds.

reviewText: So I didn't buy this game on day one like I do most Far Cry games.....I was under the impression that Ubisoft was milking the Far Cry franchise and I wanted to be no part of it. This looked like a cheap Copy and paste job. Man was I wrong...I can tell what happened. I feel like this was orginally going to be a 30 dollar release like Blood Dragon but then it ended up just being too good to not make a full release. There are alot of reused assets from FC4 and 3 but it just works so well. In fact the primal setting may make this one the best Far Cry games ever. I am loving every second of it. The soundtrack is also phenominal. The game runs great and looks even better then FC4. The story is very minimilist and works great for thje franchise. 9/10 pick this one up for sure.

reviewText:
I got the game to run, almost always at 50-60. i5 Haswell, 32gb RAM, GTX 980 Ill list the various components to the gameplay and rate them that way. Reccomendation is on personal opinion only.
1. Hunting- Pretty boring due to inept animal AI and lack of danger. 5/10
2. Gathering- Not the best change that they made, now making people run out and find resources to upgrade your village I personally didnt care for the fetching since most buildings only upgrade twice. 5/10
3. Weapons- Club, Bow, Spear, Grenades, and....uhh thats about it I guess. Headshots with a bow kill all early level humans in one shot, 4-6 take down a bear. The DLC club is meant to be swung wildly and haphazardly into the path of your enemies, since I only used that club I cant review the normal ones. The spear is pretty neat. 6/10
4. Enemies- Clubman, Spearman, Bowman, Grenademan, and Heavy. Not sure if there are more vareity since I only played 3 hours. For the most part they are pathetically easy to kill, especially if you possess the DLC club which can kill most low level creatures and humans in one shot. Suprsingly you can kill the enemy civilian women. 5/10
5. Upskirts- Balls, and Bush. Pretty odd thing to add, rule 34 incoming Pretty sure I saw a enemy and a woman having sexual intercourse in a camp (think is was called lost grotto if Im not mistaken) 69/10
6. Story- Its okay, I liked it enough to get 3 hours in, but there is no hook to the story it doesnt draw you in. 4/10
7. Animals- The variety was welcome, but most use the same animations as the last game, the bears look pretty awesome though. Beware of the orgy of goat moans as you travel through oros. 8/10
8. DLC packs- Didnt get my resouce packs, didnt even need them. 0/10
9. DLC missions-First mammoth mission was...disappointing. Mammoth was animated poorly, and unrealistic. Mammoth can run basically forever and can get killed in 2-3 hits. If you want a good laugh the physics upon death are pretty funny. 4/10
10. Enviroment- Forest, rivers, waterfalls, and mountains. Overall not bad. 9/10
Final thoughts:This game looked and seemed like it would be fun, but I guess since I was rambo in Farcry 3-4 being a bowman lost its luster. Wait until the error problems are solved then and only then buy the game, but personally  I would wait for a price drop if you want to get the game. Also make sure your computer can handle the game, the graphics are really good.
6/10

reviewText:
This is my first go at the Far Cry series, and 20-25 hours into the game I must say I'm impressed! I see that a lot of people are bashing the game for not being the same as all the previous installments in the series, others doing the same for it to be to similar to the previous games...go figure :)  So, my approach to the game was x-hours of youtubing all the Far Cry games, watching gameplay, reading way to many reviews and in the end Primal easily stood out as something different.

For me as a FC novice I found the absent of big guns and frantic shoot-outs really refreshing, while at the same time, you DO get them frantic shoot-outs and melees, only this time it's bows & arrows, spears, clubs and whatnot that makes your day. Ok, it might not be that a big difference from any gun-loaded game you played a hundred times before in that sense, but the environment, the dynamics and made-up language together with the overall ambience in the game does a pretty good job convincing me that I'm a proper 10.000 BC bad@ss hunter-gatherer :)

I'm running the game on Ultra settings on my pc, and even before I got the DLC HD-package the graphics was blowing my mind. After installing the HD-package I'd got a friend to play the game so I could just sit back and enjoy the stunning scenery of the Land of Oro.

If you're into adventure/action pc-games where you don't need eight left-hand fingers to pull out as the winner of a fight and don't have fetish on casting spells while doing acrobatics, this might be just the game for you.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
I did everything possible in this game except explore every cave and point of interest, which doesn't really get you much anyway except exploration XP and at this point XP was useless anyway, all that I did in 22 houres and I took my time doing it - and im a relatively slow player too.

The game might be way to short to be worth 60€ but that doesn't necessarily mean it's a bad game, those 22 houres were pretty fun, the world is large and pretty and the story was .. nice. Despite how short it was. It's an alright game, really. But that's just it, it's nothing more than that. The map is recycled from FC4 apparently although differently laid out so you probably won't notice when playing. The gameplay is pretty much identical to FC3 or 4 except with different fluff, this time around you can have a pet, you drop guns in favor of melee and throwing weapons, or a bow. It's pretty fun to throw spears at a Mammoth, or blow an arrow through an enemies skull but the game offers nothing special, it's a time filler game that you'll probably uninstall and never replay once you are done with it, obviously there are no multiplayer either.

I won't tell you not to play it, but I won't recommend either - it's simply not worth the price. If you are a fan of the series i'd suggest waiting until the price drops or a good sale that puts it at 20€ or so, that's more along what it's worth. I got excited and payed 65€ for the Apex Edition and I feel like I threw away my money, the bonus missions are not at all worth it either.

reviewText:
I would like to start this by saying this game is extremely mediocre but that being said im only 3.3 hours in when im writing this.

The more i continue playing this the more i wished i refunded it one hour ago the story is not compelling but im going to a pros and cons anyways.

~~~PROS~~~

-I would say graphics but the optimization is that poor i doubt an average gaming PC could run the graphics at high above 30 FPS.

-I do quite like the turn of animations setting, it saves a lot of time.

-The beast system is okay that being said the tamingsystem" in the other hand is not all you need to do throw a bit of bait then press E. Its harder to tame the first pokemon than it is to tame a cave bear.

I'm running out of pros so i'll move onto cons.
~~CONS~~

-The "optimization"
date:
if it has any.

- Weapon choice is little to none.

-The hunting system is just aim for the head and hope for the best or get your beast to do it for you.

-The story so far has been so boring that i dont even want to continue.

-Combat is incredibly easy on normal difficulty.

-The map lay out is a 'Copy and paste' of Far Cry 4 i would even say the game is a reskin of Far Cry 3/4.

The list could go on well the "cons" one anyway...

I will end on a quote

reviewText:
To start off I am going to try and make this reveiw with no spoilers.

When I first decided to buy this game I was a bit nervous based off of what other people thought. I watched a few videos on the game and thought it was interesting. So I decided to buy it regardless of what peope were saying. And I'm glad I made that decision. The game has a decent story. It's about what'd you expect considering FarCry isn't extremely story driven. The free roam is a great aspect of the game. Infact, I felt myself not wanting to do story missions because there were so many other things to do. I loved taming the beasts, especially the boss fights, it added an extra difficulty to the game. I also liked the crafting and upgrading weapons or building the Wenja bases for upgrades. But I finally beat the story and I enjoyed the entire game.

Some people were saying that the game felt like a re-skin of FarCry 4, and I can agree. The game did play and feel a lot like FarCry 4. But it wasn't in a bad way. The game had enough variety as to where it was entertaining and wasn't getting in the way. Rather than buying weapons you had to make them. Or rather than claiming bell towers you had to light bonfires. Overall I would recommend this game to most people.

reviewText:
As my first FarCry experience, I must say: superb. Granted, I realize a lot of people complain of similarities and lack of a driven campaign, but I will argue that the focus and intent of FarCry Primal is far more than most give it credit. I really apprecaite them taking the game to where they have found a niche--that being in wildlife as prey/hunter, regardless of primary missions. Personally, I like how hunting and expanding one's influence is more intended. The world is beautiful and they did great in the animations of wildlife (gotta love watching a sabor take down a deer xD ).
All that to say that the most intriguing part to me is the focus upon primative groups and natives as they were before and without technology. It was interesting seeing how they depicted cultural differences and the impact said differences has on conduct, religion, and structure. Love the recreated language! Reminds me of home xD
Yes, I grew up in such a setting.
Would rate 8.5/10. Great game; good buy.

reviewText:
This game is a far cry from a Far Cry game (says the biggest Far Cry fan ever).

With some of the best environmental atmospheres and artwork I've seen, an emense job was done to make this game outstanding. And it is. However after you get past the initial shock, the game is just a tedious scavenge for endless crafting material in an overpopulated world where you can't move 20 ft without getting attacked by something.

Somehow unlike its predecessors, the game suffers from an amazing sense of enemies spawning right behind you, even after you've just cleared out an area. The weapons become tedious and unexciting (and there are realistically only 3 weapons), the missions are dry, repetitive and mundane, the emotional character connections are completely dead, the story is as primative as the game name and the worst of it all, is the ending is completely and utterly anti-climatic. Mostly on account of there is no actual final mission, you just finish all of the main quests (in any order) and then BAM, you're done. Finally, because it was a grind getting there.

Stealth is now even more clunky and vexxing, and since the bow or knife-throw doesn't insta-kill enemies anymore there is no reliable way to ensure a stealth kill shy of a take-down or throwing a spear through their guts which sends the corpse flying across the map likely alerting others to your stealth kill". Beasts
recommended: are just going to tip off enemies
hoursPlayed: who somehow know that your beast is no normal beast but you the fkn beast master must be hiding nearby.\n\nThe key to this game is the "beast taming" - which is all well and good but then you set out to do epic beast hunts and tame super beasts after throwing everything but the hut sink at it just to pitch your new uber beast up against a single "heavy" tribesman and watch the ****ing thing lose to a single man! Which isn't so bad

In Far Cry 4

reviewText:
Was skeptical on how an early humanity game would play out. Honestly, the story fits, the combat style is interesting, and the gameplay in general was solid. The early game survival aspect lasted until mid game for me, maybe even later, and was to me a core component of immersion into the time period. The combat did to some may seem stale, but i believe the progression of combat was timed perfectly, not becoming easy until the last mission of the game. Unlike farcry 4, which was a terrible game, this game doesnt seem to force you in any set direction, and with the taming system encourages exploration, with some interesting side quests for the legendary tames towards the end of the game. I had fun doing them and once again it had shown me complete immersion while you stalk the named beasts. The only negative I have about this game is probaly how short it was, which is not really a negative because considering all the single player games ive played in the last few years, the length of this game matches perfectly, but to me being an older gamer, I am used to longer games.

Overall 10/10
voteText: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
While Far Cry Primal is a new additiion tot he series, I have played and enjoyed a majority of all the entire Far Cry games but this one has certainly taken it to another level by creating a new immersive language taking players back to the stone age and with some fun hunting the mechanic, the problem with this game although is that if you have played all the Far Cry game you will feel that the mechanic really needs a  lift. In the face of spending 60 bucks for all new materials this game lacked characters with memorable personalities that really shined as the previous Far Cry, in depth melee combat and a mechanics we have seen time and time again thus making the game feel like a spin off such as Blood dragon than an actual new Far Cry that shines.
Not a bad game but very mediocre at best and it pains me to even rate the game as I wanted to give it a thumbs up but I cannot because doing so will be telling you that its a must buy. I can recommend it if you love the setting the game offers and just want more Far Cry no matter what it is.

Video Review https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OQDJvjxS06s

Pros + The hunting mechanic in the game is well done. Tigers, Dire wolves, Mammoths so on.
+ Environment and graphics are really well done and make one feels like they are actually in the B.C period
+ The language created to go with the game is very immersive.
+ Treating my Sabertooth like a pet cat, then being able to ride it along with mammoths etc.
+ The story pacing for the subtitles is perfect so that the player can follow with the story fine.
+ Every weapon can be on fire and used to set environments on fire and thus fire is a powerful element. Very fun to use.
+ Plenty of missions and side missions to do on the map

Cons - Unmemorable characters in this game. Farcry 3 had Vaaj, 4 had Pagin Min, Primal had... who?
- The hunting to upgrade the base gets tedious after hours of hours of play to upgrade the base to progress in the story and also the lack of even customizing your tribe.
- Overused Far Cry mechanic that needs to change. Players who played all the Farcry will feel really burned out
- The map is the Farcry 4 map, placed on top of each other its the exact map and breaks immersion if you realize and spot the geological areas in the game, Farcry 4 takes place in Himalayas while Primal is supposed to take place somewhere in Europe lol so thus breaking immersion.
- The melee combat is stale without the ability to block at all and feels unengaging mostly just hit hit and move away.
- The taming could had been so much better than throwing meat and being able to summon multiple times. Felt very unrewarding when you earn the beasts in the game.
- No multiplay of any sort so replayability dies off after finishing.


Conclusion - Ubisoft has dropped the bomb on this one for me and I didn't hate it since I sat through it but if it had taken the game farther back in the period where dinosaurs existed then it would had been AMAZING. The game just felt like a spin off but at the same time didn't offer enough materials to keep me interested from sleeping at times literally.
I thought it was mediocre and to be honest I can see some people enjoying this if you never played the Far Cry series or just like the setting in general, but having played all of it I am so burned out from the same mechanics which didn't really change for this game. I hope Far Cry 5 will bring glory back to the series or else it's time for a new IP.

Check this game out if you just love Far Cry and want more, otherwise wait for price drop. It isn't a game you will want to get right away if you played every Far Cry ever expecting something new. If anything check Farcry 3 and 4 if you never played it.

reviewText:
I do recommend this game BUT not at full price.

Pros:
-Hunting and stealth is more fun than ever.
-Beautiful world to explore with lots of collectibles and such to make you see everything.
-Tame beasts that each have special abilities (jaguars can sneak attack without alerting nearby enemies). Ride some of your tamed beasts or hitch onto a wild young mammoth.  Yes, you can do mounted combat.  You can use all your weapons while mounted and your beasts will even attack as well.
-Day and night. Packs of wolves hunting at night.  You can capture an outpost at night and eliminate your enemies while they're sleeping.
-Plenty of side missions and random events.
-Skinning and harvesting have a short animation so its quick.
-Primitive weapons and crafting!  I put these two together because for every weapon you have, you build.  Harvest materials from all over the map to build and upgrade and replenish your stock of them.
-Combat with primitive weapons is really fun. You carry every weapon in the game with you. No more weapon shops where you swap loadouts.  You can do takedowns with different weapons for different kill animations.  Ignite your weapons and arrows for deadly and interesting action (sabertooth will drop and roll when on fire).
-Fire good! Fire bad! It's so useful and deadly in this game. I remember one mission where i had to burn enemy crops; I took some high ground and kept shooting in fire arrows which burned up the entire farm and most of the enemies in it. The fire spread so much that I started to take damage from it. Good times.
-Some of your beasts do takedown/kill animations when you take them hunting!

Theres some more good things I can say about this game but these are just some highlights. Now for the (not so) bad...

Cons:
-Short story. It's not rich but it's not bad either. I enjoyed the language and the historical setting. But it was way too short that it made me regret paying a full price when I've paid way less for games I haven't even beaten yet. It should have had more story missions aside from the main plot.  If I had at least 3 or 4 more story missions with Urki, I'd cry happiness.
-No multiplayer. Games are just so much more fun when you can have a buddy join in.
-No challenge for achievements.

Even though I beat the story in a fraction of the time I played this game, I enjoyed it very much. I like the far cry games and Primal is easily my favorite of them all. The gameplay keeps me glued to it and makes me want to get 100% completion. I'd start a new game after too.

You should get this game. It's fun. But buy it at a cheaper price.

reviewText: Far Cry Primal is a beautifully designed game, with a stunning environment and fantastic audio. The game play is solid and enjoyable and loaded with features. Its biggest flaw is the lack of incentive to use all the pets, skills, and features in the game because of the lack of content. The content that exists starts to get monotonous by the finish because of the copy and paste programming used to fill it up. Here is an analogy to sum up Far Cry Primal.\n\nOne of the top restaurants in the world wants to make a great dessert. They hire some of the top pastry chefs to work on it. But the restaurant is impatient and wants to start selling the dessert before the chefs have time to finish. One chef insists it is great the way it is, and the customers won't notice whats missing. When the first customers order it, they are in awe when it is brought to the table. It's one of the most beautiful desserts they have ever seen. When they taste it, it has almost no sugar. When they ask about it, the chefs say that they will add more later for an extra charge.

reviewText: Pretty blatant cash grab.  While the game in and of itself is fun.. the AAA title price point is laughable. Almost all assets were recycled from Far Cry 4 and once you get past the initial novelty (about 20 min in), the game gets old almost immediately.  All of this is made worse by the rampant BS pushed by the dev team prior to launch as to how hard they worked to make the game original, and feel unique.  Zero effort was put in to polish pre-existing systems or make the game unique other than visually.  Its a game about the survival of your tribe... with ZERO survival elements. Save your money. If you're really craving a similar caveman experience, play Far Cry 4 in your underwear and grunt a lot.

reviewText: While this game isn't necessarily 'bad', its price tag simply does not justify the gameplay. reviewText:
As many of the reviews stated, at its core it still is the same game as the previous Far Cry games.
Though, it is set in a time not many games are set in (as of my knowledge) and that's what made me look at it in a different light. The Far Cry franchise worked as it was and (for me atleast) it still does with its new par Far Cry Primal.

And now, being able to hunt my favourite creatures from that time period makes it even more enjoyable for me. This game excells at being different in comparison to the other Far Cry titles by being not that different at all. Same mechanics, mostly same animations. But the setting gives it a whole different flair with a beautifully rendered environment with a lot of potentiel to have fun in.

It may not be worth its 60$/59,99€ regular price but in my opinion it is definitely worth getting it on a steam sale (f.e. 20% off as it is now).

If you want to check out some gamplay beforehand:
Cliff-Diving for Beginners - Far Cry Primal [P1]

reviewText:
Is it the best Far Cry? No. But, it does have some great gameplay and replayability.  The graphics are decent, though I still think FC4 looked better.  I have the HD pack installed and play at 1440p and the game looks really great, still.  I really like the survivor mode.  I finished the game on Hard and once they released the survivor mode, I've been playing that. It's definitely worth replaying just for the extra challenge.

The only downside to the game is the story.  It's not interesting and isn't exciting. The gameplay is where it's at.

Performance-wise, it's better than Far Cry 4 was at launch. No microstutter.  Only a few areas where I dropped into the 40s. Mostly it was 60 + at 1440p on a 980 ti.

If you like Far Cry, you'll like the game but may find some of the gameplay too familiar to the others.
If it's your first Far Cry, I guarantee you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
THE GOOD

1. Loads of things to do
- The map is full of quests, different animals, gathering, terrain, and enemies.  Perhaps TOO full of that last one.  Sometimes it's hard to get anywhere due to all the enemy tribes you encounter, but the world feels as alive as in previous FC games.  Good but not overwhelming crafting.

2. Graphics
- They won't blow your mind.  But they look good.  Even up to pretty darn good" in a few areas.

3. Period weapons and gadgets
- If you are interested in fighting only with a bow different types of pointy and bashy sticks then this is a blast.  There's only a bit of snark there.  I always enjoy archery in games.  And you certainly get that here.  So I'm enjoying it.

4. The cut scenes
- There aren't too many of them and you can skip the vast majority.  When cutscenes are robust and advance my interest in a game then I am all for them.  Read on for reasons why you may not be interested in the cutscenes for this game.

5. The animals
- They really did do a good job with the animals.  They all have distinct sounds that you will hear off in the distance as you move about.  They behave as you would expect.  The deer are shy.  The jaguars are stealthy.  The mammoths are friendly until you ♥♥♥♥ them off.  The taming is... eh.  Not my thing.  It's alright. Not to worry. You can ignore if you want.  You've got your trusty machine-bow-and-arrow-sniper-railgun-flamethrower.


THE BAD

1. Old stanky map
- It's the FC4 map.  It underwent a small tweaking.  But it's the FC4 map.  Lazy sausage pumps...

2. Ooka Booka Language
-  Don't look away.  Don't pay attention to the art direction
hoursPlayed: or any of the other stuff on your screen. Don't go to the toilet with your headphones and listen to the story.  Just keep your eyes fixed on these subtitles if you want to have any clue what the story is about.\n\n- For those of us who watch Game of Thrones.  We know how incorporating a newly created language SHOULD be done - The Dothraki.  A language created just for one story should advance that story rather than impede it.  In GoT
voteText:
even during the Dothraki scenes we didn't get only their language.  Sometimes there weren't subtitles and a character did our translating and other times there were simply no translations at all and we relied on the visuals.  Not this game though... every scene... every word...all the way through... subtitles.  I'd like someone to find out how many times you here the fake word "Wenja" throughout the game.  A punishingly gigantic amount I can tell you.

3.  The story
- Who the hell knows what it is because of the Ooka Booka langauge.  Previouc FC have had rich stories
helpfulPercent: excellent villans (well at least one)
votesHelpful:
and rich cutscenes.  Maybe this one does.  Maybe it doesn't.  Do a lot of reading of some mediocre broken english if you'd like to find out.

4.  The gameplay
- It's simplisticly fun and easy.  When you watch your character make his first bow you think "Ah
votesTotal: this bow will be poop because it's my first one."  No no... that bow is all you need.  Son
votesFunny: that thing shoots 200 yards before the arrow starts to fall at all.  I was quite disappointed at how easy the bows are.  The melee weapons are exaftly as you'd expect them to be - not that fun.  Also

the x-ray vision and shiny loot is the kind of console-coddling that I can't stand from Ubi.

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is a great game and I recommend it to anyone who is either a fan of the Farcry series (post Farcry 2) and/or is interested in the theme of this game. I would not however, recommend it for those who enjoyed previous Farcry games purely for their gunplay, explosives, and so on.

I am writing this as of patch 2, about 3 weeks after launch, and I am still encountering a number of bugs. Specifically:

* The cutscene audio frequently goes out of sync, usually the audio goes ahead of whats on the screen
* The recap segments have spoiled elements of the story for me a few times, showing me things that hadn't happened yet
* When I try to close the program normally, it occasionally comes up with a Windows This program has crashed" error screen
* Some of the objects and people you need to interact with are extremely picky about where you need to stand in order to activate them. The worst example of this was when I needed to speak to a person who was tied to the ground
date: and I had to jump into the air and talk to him mid-air in order for the interact prompt to appear. Normally you just need to circle the person or object a few times until you find the very tiny
recommended: invisible sweet spot. This was an issue with Farcry 3 and 4
hoursPlayed: and so I can see that this is still not fixed.\n\nLastly I wanted to comment on the story. I'm a little dissappointed with it so far. I'm 20 hours in and I still don't really feel like I'm part of this vast
voteText: epic struggle as was the case in previous Farcry titles. That isn't necessarily a problem

reviewText:
Through my two full campaign playthroughs I can be pretty certain about what I think about this game.
The graphics are pretty, the game looks absolutely wonderful, the atmosphere is great, the characters are mostly great.
Though, the plot and story was just poor. For a game so beautiful the story was too short and un-inspired. Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4 left me stunned after the first playthrough, they were masterpieces. I've spent over one hundred hours on Far Cry 3, over two hundred on Far Cry 4 but just alittle over thirty on Far Cry Primal. It's not worth 59,99€ in my opinion, 40€ would be nice.

Pretty game, poor story. Far Cry game is a Far Cry game, though. I liked it. Buy this game when it drops down in price.

reviewText: So far I am absolutely loving this game. Although I am a huge Native American fan as I am half Native American. I do tend to leech to anything that has that style.\n\nI am about 10% done with the game at the moment and I have to say so much fun. I was a bit worried buying this game since the reviews seem not soo great. I listened to my gut and went for it since it was on sale. First off just let me say I have not played the other Farcry games, I know a lot of the complaints are due to the game feeling like Farcry 4. I can't really comment on that since I have never played it. The best way I can describe this game is this is exactly how I was hoping ARK would be. A fun survival game that allows you to explore, tame beasts, build huts/houses, help your fellow villagers and just do whatever you want along with doing the story, random objectives that pop up. The world feel like it is very alive. Everywhere I turn there is some sort of animal. Some that want to kill and some that do not like butterflies, birds and turtles. The scenary is very nice. I have caught my self just climbing to the top and looking at the beautiful world. I personally feel the game does a good job of setting the scenary and then bringing you into it. The native tongue they speak is something I really enjoy as well. It really makes me feel like I am back in 10,000 bc. I will most definately keep playing this game for a long time I can see, as this is a game I have been looking for for a long time. I have a hard time putting down already and continue seeing that as an issue (good issue) going forward.

reviewText:
Far Cry Primal has surprised me and is in my opinion probably the best Far Cry game thus far.

The small selection of weaponry fits perfectly into the setting and you never feel like they've added some just to fill out some random quota of how many different types of the same gun should be in the game.

The world itself is filled with animals and plant life as is expected of the setting, and the animal taming feels appropriate, taming the apex predators to give you an advantage over your enemies.

The two different groups of enemies are distinct enough from each other that it doesn't just feel like you're killing random guy with spear 7.

And finally the storyline is interesting enough to make you want to explore the quests rather than having them be a chore you need to do in order to get better equipment.

reviewText: This is my new favorite game. Maybe it's partly because I've always wanted a good prehistoric-themed game. In this you can go charging in if you want once you tame something awesome like Great Scar the cave bear. I love the feeling of roaming the world with a saber tooth tiger by my side as well. The game is controller friendly. It says partial controller support" but it uses the whole controller. The stone age weapons are refreshing to me after playing countless games with guns. I'm not sure some of the negative reviews are deserved because I noticed those players only had an hour or two on record. I have 21.9 hours logged in just two days and I still have tons to do. reviewText:
Some have criticised FC:P for the 'lack of story' but as someone who enjoyed the Far Cry formula since FC2, I think I prefer it that way.

While I think Vass, Pagan, et al, are great characters, what keeps me coming back to the Far Cry series is the core game-play.  It's more than immersive - it transports me to another place (especially when I remove the HUD elements). It doesn't just allow for emergent game play - it encourages it. If anything, I find the 'story' elements often intrude on what is otherwise an almost zen like experience for me.

I understand that some may find it repetitive; I have certainly lost interest in Assassin's Creed, (and other Ubisoft products) which are in many ways very similar, but there is something about the Far Cry series that really has me hooked.

Steam controller works well, and there are a couple of good community configs, but I wish there was an official profile for the game.

reviewText: Far Cry Primal takes the back to the stone age, where you have to rely on your survival, hoarding and hunting skills. In previous titles you had to do these things for a few upgrades. but in this version you can count on it to do it alot. You can tame different animals with different abilities to fight with, or even ride on some of them. Since it's not a shooter, you have to use different type of weapons: like bows, spears and clubs, to take out your enemies. It's a fun game to do all the main missions, but the side missions will get repetitive after a while.\n\nThe game looks beautiful and runs really smooth, and I didn't discover any setbacks or major bugs. If you enjoy the wildlife and surviving, then I recommend this game. It's a beautiful world to explore and freeroam, and fighting alongside an awesome Sabertooth Tiger feels, well, awesome.

reviewText: I've never played anything like this game.  I was hooked on the idea of a caveman adventure as soon as I seen it and I wasn't disappointed.  The takedown attacks are wickedly awesome.  Its a beatiful game world with danger lurking every where.  It very enjoyable to explore.  The animals are dangerous and intelligent foes.  I was surprised how fun the primitive weaponry was, my favorite being the spear.  I actually used most of the weapons and items as well, which is surprising for me since in most games I pick my favorite and stick with it most of the time.  The animal companion is a blast, I kept switching them out just to watch them duke it out with the enemies.  My high point in the game was when my bloodfang sabertooth jumped on the back of a mammoth and brought it down.  Even the badger can be fun.  He's useless when it comes to hunting, but I got a lot of amusement watching him tackle udam & izila warriors.  From stealthily moving through dark caves to charging side by side with my great scar bear into an enemy stronghold, I found this game very satisfying from start to finish.

reviewText:
Far Cry Primal is an open world, story driven, FPS game set on pre-historic time (10,000 BC). You play as Takkar, a Wenja (some kind of a tribe) warrior that is trying to conquer the Land of Oros for his people. Conflict starts when Takkar found out that Oros is conquered by Udam (cannibal tribe) in the north and by Izila (Sun worshipper) in the south. Far Cry Primal introduces several new features and an entirely new story 'pattern' compared to its predecessors. You are no longer a badass rambo-like warrior or a teenager stranded in an island or a remote area. The main new feature is the taming capability. Along the journey, Takkar was introduced to his skills as a Beast Master, capable to tame dangerous predators and even ride it after you have reached a certain level. In short, Far Cry Primal is a fresh new idea in the Far Cry series that offers the same gameplay pattern but with new environment, features, and challenges.

First off, I'm going to talk about the good things. It still has the same gameplay pattern as other Far Cry series - you still have to conquer 'radio towers' (now called bonfires) and enemy encampments while completing your journey in the main story at the same time. It still have the same epic graphics like Far Cry 4 but the story pattern is completely new. Hunting has become a major element in Far Cry Primal since you have to craft everything instead of purchasing it directly from a store. Takkar also has Assassin's Creeds' Eagle Vision that can track animal tracks, blood scents, and enemy heat signatures. This is vital in helping you hunt for animals, especially rare animals. If you love hunting games, Far Cry Primal might not be as realistic as an actual hunting game but it's satisfying enough for me. You will also progress faster compared to previous Far Cry because you'll get permanent XP boost if you rescued a lot of other Wenja (remember the impromptu events). The combat system is obviously very different, there were no guns yet so you only have clubs, throwing shards, several different 'bombs', bows, and spears. You can't butcher the whole base from afar with a .50 cal sniper rifle again, you have to come up close for most of the combat - even the long bow only give you so much attack distance. Their effort to create their own pre-historic language is also worth mentioning, I always respect game developers that pay a lot of attention to details in their games.

Now, the bad things. The content is a lot less compared to Far Cry 4 in order to make it 'makes sense'. But come on, the throwing shards, grappling hooks, animal taming, animal riding, and a ton of other features already don't make sense in the first place. The 'radio tower' part is also much shorter, you won't need to climb anything. Simply kill several enemies, shoot a fire arrow and boom, you're done. No more parkour-ing to the top of a tall tower. Map is also smaller-ish (I'm no expert in measuring virtual stuff) but it's adequate. They really should have put more features in the game. Now, the story. I somehow feel it's much less engaging and very short. As you see from my gameplay, I finished this game only in 23 hours. That 23 hours already gave me a TON of time to fool around completing the side quests, crafting everything, complete my beast collection, and building my village. IMHO, this is the reason a lot of people harshly dismissed this game as a Far Cry 4 re-skin with less content. The short story, little amount of weapon choice, and the less content disappointed them. The main beast taming feature simply couldn't make it up to the amount of lost content. To make it clear, the specific 'lost content' for me is the long and beautifully written story, fighting arena, flying, lots of weapon choices, engaging story, capability to make choices that will affect the outcome of the story, etc.

But, I still personally love the Far Cry series. I don't really care much about the less content, it's still 23 hours of fun for me. As I said in my thesis, it's a fresh new idea. An entirely different age, a different combat system, different story 'taste' and basically, as long as it's a Far Cry series, I don't care about the reviews - I want to play it. As an analogy, same thing goes for the PAYDAY 2 DLCs, the weapons may be useless and all but as long as it's something new, I want it, regardless of the mostly negative review. I'm not saying this game is 'bad but buy it', it's good and it's worth it, but don't expect to have the same experience as the previous Far Cry series. If you're looking for a very long gameplay, go for Far Cry 4, but if you don't mind the bad things that I mentioned, this game is heavily recommended.

reviewText:
A lot of people claim this game is boring and repetitive -- While It can feel repetitive after a while, the game is as fun as you make it. The main story is long enough, if you include side missions, and if you want to upgrade your gear and village to maximum, and if you go out of your way to tame all the beasts, that adds some time too.

With the issue with there not being very likeable characters -- just because the characters do not speak English, doesn't make them any less likeable. Each character has his/her own reasons for being a part of Takkar's village, and their own reasons for disliking the enemy factions. They all have their own personalities, and are different from each other.

In conclusion I find it a really enjoyable game, it's nice to take a breath from Guns and cars and modern tech, and work with the basics. The growing of your character makes that game feel like it progresses very well, and the growing of your village as more and more people join makes the game feel alive. Stunning visuals even on lower graphical settings.
