reviewText:
A lot of the initial reviews of this game were negative due to the poor PC optimization.  I waited a bit to buy it and after beating it I can say that Ubisoft has fixed the problems.  The game looks beautiful and runs smoothly.  Overall I strongly recommend this game.

I was initially a little hesitant to try this game. A Far Cry game without guns was hard to picture but the combat in Far Cry Primal is fast paced and fun.  I find it especially satisfying to crack skulls with my two handed club and there is enough of a variety of weapons to keep things interesting.

One area that this game falls short on is stealth.  Being good at stealth is something I have prided myself on in earlier Far Cry games.  The opportunities to employ stealth in this game though are few and far between and since a lot of the environments are relatively flat it is nearly impossible to clear some outposts completely without being seen.

I would put the pets in both the pro and con column.  While it’s pretty awesome to be able to tame a sabretooth cat or a bear and even ride them, at times they are so overpowered that they almost trivialize combat.  Kind of like how in Far Cry 4 you could throw a couple pieces of bait into an outpost and the random bears and tigers that show up would do all the work for you.  They are a big help with hunting though.

My only major gripe about this game though is the story; there really isn’t much of one.  For most of the game you are completing quests and acquiring villagers or completing quests given to you by said villagers.  Eventually you complete enough quests that you fight and eliminate the rival tribes in the valley and just like that the game is over.  At no time does the game really feel like it has a solid cohesive narrative.  I mostly felt like I spent 60 hours playing non-stop side quests and by the time it was over I was glad for a break.  It was definitely entertaining along the way though and I wager the next time I play through I will probably be able to shave off about 20 hours since I will know what I am doing so the last half of the game won’t drag on so long.

If you are a fan of the series I don’t think you will be disappointed in buying this game.

reviewText:
As someone that hasn't been able to play through a Far Cry game since 2 came out, I must say that so far this game has redeemed the series. I am hesitant to compare the game on that note however, considering the fact that it generates a world that feels entirely different than previous games.

Wildlife feels dangerous until you're better equipped. Night-time is accompanied by an increased traffic of carnivorous animals that of course only furthers itself as you travel away from your Village. Every enemy will become increasingly agressive as you progress further into the world. At first a pack of wolves hunting game might seem trivial, with you crouched in the bushes ready to strike. Though as soon as a cave lion, a group of yak, and a mammoth walk into the picture... you're met with a sudden sense that things could get very bad. They usually do.

I can almost guarantee your first encounter with a Sabretooth will leave you wanting one of your very own, so long as it doesn't eat you first.

There is slightly more gathering than you might expect, though the game includes a Rewards Stash." Your stash will increasingly flow with free "loot" items (wood

reviewText:
I find it utterly hilarious how people bash this game for not delivering on the ''survival'' aspect. Nobody said it would be survival, its is Farcry in the primal age and it does it well.

So, my personal opinion so far after gloriously riding my blood drenched sabertooth into battle is that its a solid and interesting new edition to the farcry franchise. A breath of fresh air in a franchise that direly needed it. The combat is visceral and hilariously satisfying. From the thumping sound of hitting someone with a club to watching your badass pet take down a person in the most merciless of ways.

Gathering is solid and for the first time to me, actually fun. I dunno if its actually different or I finally let it in but its a lot more satisfying then it used to be to me. Building up your village is somewhat meh but it is pretty fun to watch it grow and gain the new abilities associated with it.

If you like visceral combat, satisfying hunts and a decent story. I don't see why you shouldn't get this game. If you expect ARK... why not get that game instead?
voteText: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: While I understand the frustrations with Ubisoft and feel complete sympathy for those getting startup/crashing errors, if you are able to get the game working its pretty enjoyable. Some have commented that this game feels too simalar in style to the previous two games, and in some ways that is true. However, its not a bad thing. The Far Cry theme fits very well with this time period. In fact, it feels more realistic and on edge knowing that at any moment you could be attacked by a gang of cannibals or a sabertooth tigher. The gameplay, once you get it down, is really fun and brutal. If you like melee and traditional forms of combat, you will probably enjoy this. The graphics are also very nice, even on low settings the game is stunning. The combat upgrades, control over various animals, and the village building system all give Far Cry Primal a unique feeling. Definitely worth a try for those of you that are skeptical.

reviewText:
I love the Far Cry series, it is one of my favorite video game series ever. When I heard about Primal I was hardly disappointed due to lack of guns because I knew the true spirit of the game would go uninterrupted.

Stealthly taking over outposts via bows and knives.

Aiming with bows has changed the game (without reticle). Previous installments allow you to aim with iron sights. The bows in Primal don't have them. Your shots fly about one arrowhead (drawn) north, directly on the left edge of your intial arrowhead position before the draw. This makes aiming with a drawn arrow difficult without practice, albeit a fresh challenge. However if that type of aiming with the bow carried over to previous installments or other games, that would not be good. It may be reason to turn the reticle on. Other than that the game is a new twist on old Far Cry fashion. I've enjoyed it so far.

If you enjoyed Shangri-La, you will enjoy Primal. If not, skip this one.
If you have never played a Far Cry title before I would not reccomend this as an entry to the series because it's probably best fit for a particular playstyle.

no more guns, you either use a very skillful arrow or stealth and a spear to the face, helping you do this is a decent list of different animals, instead of a camera you have a bomb dropping owl and instead of being some faceless whimp who becomes rambo you are allready sort of a badass but i geuss the stone age will do that to a man.

one cool thing is that as you save people, do side missions and generally help out people your cave grows and grows into some kind of stoneage base of operations and it even comes with a big old trophy room for everything you have done which is a nice touch.

main commplaints is that there is some odd bugs and performance issues going on and the combat and new taming system is a little bare but i have never had an error message, do not get me wrong i am sure day 1 connections isssues are totally worth giving a game a 0/10 and dissmissing everything else right? haha right.

*EDIT*
after playing for 5 hours more i can give a little more insight.

-you build, protect and mantain a village of your own which is a nice little edition to farcry
-the owl has skills, from a long cooldown free kill to dropping bombs that is new and fun and 10x better than a camera
-i can ride a bear into battle with a spear, sling, bee bombs and enough leather to look like a bear, amazing.
-I CAN RIDE A SABERTOOTH TIGER
-srsly did you just read that last part?
-hunting with tiger and spear at night is amazingly good fun

As someone who hasn't touched the FarCry franchise before, I am thorougly enjoying this game. I like the open world style roaming, crafting your own weapons, being able to light them on fire before using them. Taming various beasts to then use to fight with with you.

voteText: 17 of 33 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dont usually do reviews for games but feel that this game has received far too many negative and unfair reviews (imo) which have resulted in making it harder for people to decide on whether to get the game. From what i have seen, a lot of the poor reviews are from people that are having problems due to their own computer issues and thus it is often easier to just blame the game. I struggle to see why fans of the Far Cry series would not like this game. It is stunning in every way.

I have played all of the Far Cry series and after playing just 2.9 hours of this one so far, i am completely blown away and addicted. Graphics are breathtaking and i have had no issues at all so far. Game is being played with all settings maxed out (Ultra) @ 1920x1200 and it is smooth as silk (i7 4790K @4GHz OC'd to 4.7, 16GB Memory, R9 390 @8Gb).  In the 3 hours i have played, i still havent even hit 4% of the game yet. The map is massive and the beauty of it compels you to explore and take in the scenery and explore some more. Easier to give you an example of what i mean. I was wondering across the mountains and decided to find a nice spot and sit and wait for some birds to fly across with Bow and Arrows at the ready. To my left, a huge Elk came wandering by. Me being a bit itchy fingered i drew back the bow and fired an arrow into the Elk. Unsurprisingly it ran away and so i continued in wait to line a good shot up on some birds. 5 Minutes later, i received a pair of huge Elk Antlers up my back side. It had circled and flanked me and attacked me savagely. While i was trying to back away and react, a Wolf jumped on the Elk and tore it to shreds. I waited till the Elk was dead and then killed the wolf and skinned them both. Then i continued on with my bird hunt and eventually got a couple. At this rate i am going to have many hours of breathtaking fun. Money well spent and anyther great Far Cry game. Possibly even the best of the series.

That is what Far Cry Primal brings you. Unique experiences, beauty and complete freedom. Would definitely recommend. Abolutely love the game.

reviewText: I dont know why this game is getting so many bad reviews. Just because of that i decided i should probably write my own review for it. The game is really fun and addicting. I dont see why people are complaining about the graphics as on ultra with SMAA they do like quite stunning with the classic far cry feel. The gameplay is in no way a rehash of the other far cry games as it feels very different and more unique persay. The storyline is feint but its not terrible although its not fantastic either. I really like this game after only playing it for around 6 hours and will probably add many more hours into the game.

reviewText: Copy and paste the exact same mechanics as the previous games reskinned with a prehistoric vibe.  Then remove a huge chunk of variety that previous Far Cry games brought to the table with tons of weapons and gadgets.  Also remove interesting antagonists like Vaz and compelling motivation like seeing your brother killed.  Enemies will detect you from insane distances, sometimes without line of sight in classic Far Cry fashion.  To anyone who says it's not fair to judge this game by it's predecessors, I don't know what to tell you.  If a game comes out that's a copy of a previous game but worse, the comparison draws itself.\n\nThe game is very pretty.  I loved the lighting and scenery.  The few new elements like taming animals and improving your village are interesting. However the pet AI is bad and even though there are lots of different animals to tame, it is easy to get some of the best pets early on which makes the others pointless.  The village upgrading seems more like an excuse to convince you to run around and gather more resources that are scattered every five feet.  Heavies make a reappearance, but without the variety of items in previous Far Cry games the only viable way to fight them is the heavy takedown skill which removes a lot of the flexibility that made taking outposts a fun challenge instead of a timewaster.  The game takes a stab at variety with the bee bombs, berserk bombs, and fire bombs but in the end they are all useful as distractions at best against stronger enemies.  One weapon they really got right was the spear.  It is extremely fun to use melee and ranged but they break after a few uses and you will never have more than a few of them at a time.  The game will let you carry more two-handed clubs than spears for some reason.  And that basically defines this game.  The things this game does that are fun are too few and hard to come by.

reviewText:
Besides requiring U-Play to play the game. It has been an enjoyable experience.

Remember Far Cry with Guns... (this doesn't have guns) so if you a patriotic asshat this game isn't for you.

Okay onto the real review. You are a sexy caveman called Takkar. You have the power of gray...
I mean you become a beast master, explorer of caves and more importantly... ♥♥♥♥-man...

The gameplay starts off pretty brutal at first. The animals in the environment that will fight against you.
(Once you start taming your dino... animals) The game becomes easier to the point where you can do anything.

While you are playing the game on the menus you might get a reduced frame rate. This is caused by the intense flame animations (which aren't required). You may also glitch through walls in some missions... But for me this has only happened to me once... (Gathering materials can glitch you through walls).

If you enjoyed Far Cry 3. This game is for you.

reviewText: If you're here looking for bad reviews, a lot of these people haven't actually gotten deep enough into the game to experience the amazing upgrades, the several different animals you can tame. Did I meantion you can also ride some of them? Or they are complaining about crashes or glitches etc. I have put about 15 hours in of actual gameplay. I have not yet experienced anything gamebreaking or that is annoying. Once The game was lagging and I just had to restart it and it was working fine afterwards. This game is great, It is so much fun, the graphics are beautiful and I just cannot keep from playing it. However my only problem with the game, not sure if it's a glitch or what, but if you tame a Cave Bear, you cannot mount it. But the cave bear out puts a lot of damage and can take a lot of hits. But I would like it if we could ride the Cave Bear instead of just a regular bear, because I mean you can ride a mammoth, So we should be able to mount it. But overall this is my favorite Far Cry game. I enjoy the different weapons, Like there are three types of bows, Just a regular Bow, then you have the longbow, and my personal favorite is the Double Bow where you shoot two arrows at once. Did I mention you can ride a Mammoth. This game is so much fun, sometiems it does seem repetitive, for example, the Bonfires/Outpost, but so were the towers in Far Cry 3. You ran up a tower, and you got a piece of the map. Kinda the same except you have to kill some enemies then light the bonfire. But other than that the missions are fun. I would defintley but this game, I'm not even halfway through the game and i've got 16 hours in it.

reviewText: I know people are saying this is just a rehash of Farcry 4, well its not....good Lord it is not. I will say there are animals that may be used again but jesus they can't go and invent new animals and the animals fit the enviroment. The crafting, gameplay, taming, scavaging, its all new and feels awesome. Exploring caves that reveal a story of paintings, discovering villages that were massacred. There is so much to do. Every time i log on to play i fee like i have discovered so much and then i look at my progress and it says 14.6% complete. If everything i have done so far is only that much then I have a long game to go. If you turn off all of the HUD elements its an amazing experience. The story is not bad at all, I feel like it is a better story than FC4, but thats me. Remeber this is all my opinion but so far this is my favorite Far Cry.

I don't understand how this game can possibly have bad reviews... it truly boggles the mind.
The story is amazing,the gameplay is addictive and fun, and the atmosphere it creates is perfect. There is all sorts of fun ♥♥♥♥ to do and I can already tell you with 100% certainty that I will be coming back to this game again and again well after I beat it.

reviewText:
Music- overall good although can be a bit dramatic at times, but it never feels out of place.
Performance- I run a 780 ti, 8gb ram, and a i5 4690k. Its pretty good, i am getting 50-60 fps on max setting, sometimes i dip lower for whatever reason, but this is only about 5-10% of the time.
Story-good concept, and emotionally draws me in after you have ur first battle against the udam, but as far as the enjoyment of the quests so far, i am not very pleased (i am also not that far in, so i plead ignorance here)
Hunting-ok this is some beef i have, you are almost always in hunter vision if you want to be effective which i hate, and i knew i would hate that, it makes everything grey and super yellow glows, it can be destructive to the immersion. I do like how you have to hunt for food now in order to heal instead of having an unlimited number of bandages to put over that one bullet stuck in your forearm (farcry 3 & 4). But the hunter vision annoys me, i wish i could play the game without it and still do good, but its tough, i also really am bother by the sheer amount of creatures and people, its the stone age, i didnt know there would be this many humans to bump into, also i am bothered by animals literally running into me there are so many, i would think animals would be better at avoiding humans, and also maybe having less than 100 deer in a small valley that would probably realistically have under 10 or so animals in it... oh there is also your whole tribe living in that valley.. and the cannibals. This is somethign i really dislike, the amount of people and animals is literally tooooooo much, i know this could be easily modded on the PC i am just waiting for someone to do it, PLEASE someone do this. i really like the environments though, and hunting is much more interesting with the tall grass. Its also nice that animals bleed out and what not.
Weapons-People complain about the weapons, but i think they are fine, maybe it should be a little bit harder to make one and have them last longer, they do feel a bit like minecraft as far as the duration and useage goes. But maybe that goes hand in hand with the sheer amount of ♥♥♥♥ im killing. Dont expect a vast array of weapons to pick from, its the ♥♥♥♥ing stone age. Your lucky you get as many that are actually in the game. So i am pleased here. And getting headshots with the bow is very satisfying with the one hit kill (which is realistic!! this should happen!!)
immersion- i think i would be alot more immersed if it wasnt for the damn number of things i bump into, it feels less like your hunting and more like your fighting a bunch of mobs from a mmo when this happens. I really would like to see the nights be a bit more hazardous too, also i feel like less npcs in general would be better, and maybe make hunting last longer than just using the hunter vision, and shooting an arrow at a deer and using hunter vision to go find it after it dies. perhaps a more manual mode of finding these blood trails would have been better, and of course with less animals in general it would create a higher risk of missing because you cant just go find another  so easily.
All in all though, its decent thus far, i think if they had made a few more changes (cough cough, had me on the game design team xD) it would have been alot more immersive than it is, it has alot of potential, and the stone age idea is fun as all get out (if you are in any way drawn to the savageness of what humans are then you will enjoy it). overall with my short play time, i would give this game a 8/10, although with a few simple tweaks it could easily be a 9 or a 9.5. i would still recommend this game.

reviewText: You know a game is on to something when you spend hours just aimlessly wandering and don't regret it. This is the first game to accomplish that (for me) since The Witcher 3. The environment in Far Cry Primal is rich, diverse, vibrant, and beautiful. Sometimes I just have to stop and admire the scenery. The story is somewhat primitive (yeah, I know), but it's enough to keep you engaged and give you some direction. As some others have mentioned, you might find the game more enjoyable and immersive if you disable some of the UI features, especially the minimap. The game is not particularly difficult, even on the 'hard' difficulty setting; however, it's still very enjoyable. There's just something to be said about using a pet owl to drop fire bombs on a village before charging in on the back of a sabertooth tiger and impaling people with spears. The only thing I don't like is no option for third-person view. First-person is great for shooters, but I'd much prefer third-person for games like this with primarily melee/throwing weapon combat. Overall, 9/10.

reviewText: Ok so for some reason the splash screen error happened to almost everyone. If you go into your firewall settings turn firewall off and boot the game it will run. Then after the it gets to the menu you need to close the game and go back into your firewall settings and enable your firewall. Then you should be able to launch the game like any other game and have your firewall up. For some reason it only happend on the initial boot of the game. Now that I have figured that out and have played for about 5 hours now I would have to say wow. The graphics are stunning some people are complaining about fps drops I have not so far. However I do have two GTX 970's on board with intel I7 also. The game runs smooth for me almost fully maxed out with minor tweaking and the stone age world is amazing. I would say go for a harder game setting to enjoy the game to the fullest potential. I really like the crafting and have not progressed to far in the story, only because like in every far cry game I try to craft, build, discover, unlock all I can before I progress any farther in the story. So far enjoyed the game minus having to figure out how to get around the error message at the beginning. I hope that once others either do what I said to play the game or UBI release a patch they go back in and fix the horrible reviews, becuase this potentially could be one of the best Far Cry games to date. Personal favorite is Far Cry 3 however this could very well take its place. Being able to tame the beasts and use them to help fight is pretty entertaining. To be able to tame an animal is a little to easy however, and wish you could give more commands to the animals, like weak fast attack, strong attack, charge, stealth, etc..... that would make the beast aspect of the game more challenging and honestly a little more interesting. However with all the flaws I still would say this game is pretty sweet.

reviewText:
Ok, this is late, but I swore to myself that once I get into the swing of things and get rather used to the FP area, I can try to understand just what the hell am I doing.

So without further ado, here's my uptake on the game called Far Cry: PRIMAL.

The story is amazing, first off, I like the transition from modern times to an age where we as humans, didn't care much about things, didn't bother with politics, (most of the time anyways.) and the only worry was two things: Food, and surviving the next day. That was, in itself, one of my favorite points.  And I love history, especially of animals, creatures and how a time was, that no museum can match up to.  You, as a human, WAS NOT on the top of the food chain.  The creatures then, were not afraid of you and WILL KILL YOU like any other animal that they want to eat.

The gameplay ...  Ubisoft, I know there was A LOT you want to bring into the game.. but you put WAY TOO MANY DISTRACTIONS!  I am TRYING to save my people!  I am TRYING to get my people better equipped with supplies of food, skins, stones and safety of all things, and you put events and sidequests and question marks and showing me who's walking this way, be it Uldam or the other tribe that I CAN'T GET TO because of the DISTRACTIONS!  Do you WANT ME to get these creatures or NOT!?  How would you feel if you were trying to get a good business deal going and someone is constantly tapping your shoulder and wanting you to sing Daisy Girl after you already sang it 6 times?  Sounds fun right?  Sounds good right?  NO!  If anything, this could have been corrected by somehowmaybe (I did that on purpose. That isn't a typo.) placing the distractions until after a certain point, or maybe beating the game ONCE and then you can do whatever you want. (I mean, I get it it's a FTR and all that jazz, but how can I enjoy something when I'm being told that my people are being slaughtered and they are OFTEN on their own and there's over 5 ULDAM going after their ♥♥♥!?)

I know this was lengthy.. but one thing I also need to clarify.  After finding out what I was trying to figure out what do I do in the guardian chase (to learn the taming)  and I have found A LOT of people who were having this difficulty.  I'll be frank.  WHERE THE [BLEEP] WAS YOUR DAMN INSTRUCTIONS!  You had us following our brother to go after the mammoth baby by those instructions, but OH NO!  You didn't include what the [BLEEP] to do when we have to chase the guardian! Did you guys REALLY check everything?  I mean, I heard you guys failure rate's absurdity, and I completely understand the need to quench the fan base's thirst for a new game, but COME ON!  Clean the quarters out of your ears and do it right!  If you're seeing how Capcom, Sega and another company, I forget who..is failing majorly bad by releasing terrible and yet was so hyped games, shouldn't you be learning from this?

The music.  Wait, I caught some glimpses of music, but not much of it.  I suppose this was one of those where the music feature is taken out during the actual gameplay, so you can immerse yourself in the atmosphere of the prehistoric era.  the only times where music really was needed was when I was fighting the Uldam or when I completed a goal to move the story along.

For the most part, this is good, but again.. way too many distractions.

reviewText:
Crouching in the grass, bow in my hand, scouting for prey. I spot this incredible elk, twice my size with giant antlers. I take a shot at it, and my arrow hits it in the side. It runs away. I chase after the beast, switching to  my spear. I lose sight of it when it runs into a tree line, however, its still on my mini map. The red arrow is still moving fast in the opposite direction....then turns around and bee lines straight towards me. I don't have enough time to raise my spear when it barges out of the bushes and knocks me to the ground, taking away half of my health. I rise up and throw a spear into its back. It runs and circles around for another charge. I take out another spear and go to raise it up to throw it when....the screen starts rumbling. Three mammoths, two adults and a baby, bound towards me. I throw my spear into the babies face, but its no use. It tramples over me, and its company roar and stomp the ground in front of me. I equip my bow, hoping to at least take out the elk. By the time I turn back to my left, its already less than 5 metres away from me, mid-charge. I die.

10/10 don't recommend 10,000 bce

reviewText:
After getting born in this planet, we are listening so much things about Stone Age. What really happened before, how people survived from dangerous animals, how was the life on Stone Age. Well, the answer of all these questions you can get from FACRY PRIMAL. We can be familliar and get known about Stone Age if we experience this title. As usually, we don't know the view of Stone Age or the world 10,000 B.E.C ago. In this title, we can experience the Stone Age as Takkar. We can see many types of plants, animal, surviving weapons. In that age, you have to survive by carrying few types of weapons with you to hunt down dangerous animals and get foods for yourself. You can't survive a single day without light of fire and sharpness of blades. All we know that age was the beggining of humanity. We trust everything about Stone Age's life what we hear from the history. But now you can lively experience it yourself on Stone Age through FARCRY PRIMAL. Feel the pain of injustice what Udam did with Wenja Brothers. Feel the way of how humans changed their fate. but there is bit problem with language because i have to understand the whole story with just English subtitle, well overall it's massive. The most interesting thing is Mammoth for me what i wanted see the most, too big and scary also Saber Toothed Tigers looks far scarier then other animals. So now lemme say about coolest things about this title.

Gameplay
I'm really enjoying the open world activity of this game. I can collect various types of things to craft new weapons and important meterials for me like Woods, Slate, Flowers, Leaves. I have to hunt down animal for getting suffiecient foods for me. Because you need enough food to replenish your health when you are attacked or wounded. The atmosphere of this game is too scary and gloomy. Sometimes the roar of sabre toothed tigers and wolfs frightens me the most of all at night. Because that's Stone Age not modern generation so there is only dark calls at night. So only fire on the club can figure your way out at dark night. Because all the animals awakes at night for their prey. Also, you have to explore the entire world to find story missions and side quests. Though the map is full of missions and activities.

Graphics Quality
FARCRY PRIMAL came up with breath stopping GFX this time, just truly remarkable and mind blowing if you ask me i would say it. At night it looks more amazing and thrilling as hell. In every point of view, graphics quality looks quiet attracting. You can stop yourself from capturing beautiful shots at every view of it. So i just said my opinion about it.

Optimization
FARCRY PRIMAL is really tremendously optimized masterpiece. I'm playing with very high settings means all the options are maxed out on Intel Core i5 4690K, Ram 8GB DDR3, R9 290 Vapor-X 4GB GDDR5, S2240L Monitor, 1080P display. Firstly, from a technical point of view, the game is running great: a steady 60 FPS with no dips on R9 290 Vapor-X. So it's providing me remarkable smooth performance.

Errors, Crashes, Bugs
Well, till now i didn't found any kind of bugs and get any crashes nor errors. But sometimes it takes quiet a long time on first launch loading sreen which is really wierd for everyone usually.

Language
As we know FARCRY PRIMAL is based on Stone Age so basically there is no chance of English. So you have to understand the story by just reading English subtitle.

New functions and stuffs
In this title, you can collect more crafting materials for better experience on gameplay. You can upgrade all the things you are using for surviving in game. Also, you can get skills by completing missions and gaining quiet numbers of XP. You can gain XP from every activity like headshots, animal hunting, completing hunting missions, discovering caves or secret places. Also you can test benchmark now if you want.

Most Amazing Things
You can tame Wolfs, Saber Toothed Tigers, Baby Mammoths if you want them to make a great advantage for you on combating moments. Basically combat will decrease the health of your tamed pets so you can use meats to feed them and replenish their health. If you complete side missions, you will be rewarded with populations for your village. You can use Owl to indentify enemies around the world and mark them as beast master.
Pros :::
+You can explore the world and discover secret places to gain more XP for your level
+Open world is bigger than ever
+Best atmospheric game in your choice
+Most beautiful graphics quality yet
+Enjoyalbe gameplay activity
+Tremendous and perfect optimization

Lemme rate this game in few ways
-Gameplay 9/10
-Graphics Quality 9/10
-Combating 8/10
-Optimization 10/10
-Characters 7/10
-Atmosphere based on Stone Age 10/10
-Soundtrack as atmospheric 8/10

So that's all i can say about this game for now. Becayse i haven't made so much progression on this game to explain you more. So i'm surely recommending this game for everyone, i hope it won't make you dissapointed.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I've ever played.

Ubisoft is getting a lot of hate on Primal because people are directly comparing the game to previous Farcry titles. It's not really about being a Farcry game here. This game is the best, most immersive, BEAST MASTER game. You can do everything you want as a beast master and hunter. The game has a ton of dynamic features and random events, making it fun to play with or without the story missions. The map is huge and the ecosystem/animal interaction is so immersive and alive. I play the game on the highest difficulty with almost all of the hud turned off, including the mini-map so my experience is more geared toward immersion and challenge but I think it's integral to experiencing this kind of game properly. All I'm saying is: don't judge Primal as a Farcry sequel or another hardcore survival sim. I'ts a great simulator of something very specific and somewhat fictional.

Try shutting of all of the unneeded HUD elements, playing on expert, and never use the hunter vision unless you really have to. It'll be way more fun.
voteText: 16 of 33 people (48%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Imagine Blood Dragon, but on a scale of a 'big' Far Cry game - cool, right?
Well, not so much, when everything besides farming aspect stays on the level of an addon.

There is just not enough new features and improvements, even the map is a reworked version of FC4. There are no guns, obviously, so the quantity of weapons at our disposal is basically limited by 4. Four! There's barely any story, and playing through it will take you some three, maybe four hours. Magic 'four' again.
What's there to do but the story, you ask? Ho-ho, we've got the whole package for you.
Farm. FARM. F-A-R-M. Stones, rocks, sticks, leaves, animals, chicks (for food, don't get your hopes up).

However, FC3's core gameplay is still present, and with a little addition of animal companions (not such a big thing as advertised, though) it is still enjoyable enough - hence my game time, and my positive recommendation.
Primal might be a good pick on the Summer Sale. But not for $60.

reviewText:
Yes, this doesn't have all the guns and explosives that we have all become too eager to expect from modern games.
Yes, this is basically Far Cry 4 with technology from 10,000 years ago.

But that is exactly what it is supposed to be. And its somewhat refreshing to be given such limited tools and equipment.

Do not compare this to other first person titles, or the previous Far Cry games as you will be dissapointed.
That being said, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing cool if you can appreciate what Ubisoft is trying to create. The whole point is to try to depict what it would've possibly been like to exist, hunt and craft 10,000 years before high tech weapons, computers and the internet. And I think they have done a fairly good job.

Don't take this game too seriously, but all in all it is very immersive and allows you to momentarily step into the life of a primitive" human being. Life back then wasn't easy
date: people from this period of Earth's history had to make do with whatever they could create with their bare hands. So I think that everyone who is criticising it based on the somewhat "lackluster" features should consider the context and setting of this game. Yes
recommended: some of the crafting is hard to believe
hoursPlayed: and yes some of the dialouge is somewhat humourous
voteText:
but let's not forget that this is a depiction of reality from a time where we know very little.


Anyway
helpfulPercent: I think many people who have enjoyed the Far Cry franchise will enjoy this latest installment
votesHelpful: if you take into account the context and setting.\n\nHappy hunting."

reviewText: First of all, what a great game, it is extremely enjoyable and I absolutly love the enviroment, and, as always, the Farcry team have created amazing characters that you remember and love. Tensay the Shaman has nearly topped Pagun MIn.\nThe game on the surface is a generic retextured Farcry game, it has collectables strongholds etc, but at its core it is very different, if you try and play this game like a normal Farcry game you will find it boring and uneventful, but if you really get into the feel of Oros and wander around, explore go out of your way to just find some stone, something like that, thats when you really enjoy the alive world of Oros, not fast travelling everywhere, skipping cutscenes, not stopping to check that out or not killing that animal. I have heard other people describe some of the game as pointless busy work, and I can definitly see that, but I feel if you treat it like busy work it oviosly will be, you have to treat it as an adventure, rather than doing it because you have too. Rather than gettign those logs on the way to a mission, just go out into the world, get lost, and explore. If you can't tell already I'm a big fan. But warning for those who are expecting mission to mission first, person kill sprees, beware, you can play it like but its very boring if you do.\nP.S, if you are a Nvidia graphics card user you may have to update your drivers before the game runs smoothly, I had multiple framerate and CPU problems with the game untill I downloaded the driver off Geforce experience, but don't let this put you off, its extremly easy, just open the app and click upate drivers. reviewText:
Story
The overall story is you return to homelands to discover another tribe has taken control of the lands and you play a mixture of minigames\Quest's, alongside the main storyline missions, to return the lands to your people.

Some of the mini games and side stuff get extremely annoying and repetitive and often want me to log of and take a break. Not so much fun as a chore from time to time. But you can choose your current mission and move from storyline missions to quests as you desire.

Graphics
it looks awesome at any of the preset options (low, medium, high, very high, ultra) I recently switched to a single monitor to run at ultra settings and whilst there are difference of course, im going back to triple monitors on lower settings for more immersion.

Because that is where the secret lies with primal, The immersion factor when your doing the main story is fanatastic, and on multiple monitors it really is a treat since it has better support than most for this option with no icons being all the way to one side, as it will place all the HUD information on your central screen.

Gameplay
It claims to have ties to survival bloodlines, but truthfully its not any more survival than what you might expect from a regular title. Dont Expect the survival tag to deliver content such as ark survival, Stranded Deep, Etc...

And the crafting is more geared towards weapon upgrades and not construction, but you do upgrade a small village as you playthrough the game. This is achieved by going out and resource collecting, but thanks to rewards it can be achieved at a less choreful pace if desired.

Also tagged as Open World, and despite having a large map it will at times it will feel like the scenary is shaped to guide you along a set pathway. In freeroam mode whilst not on missions is where this tag applies.

Conclusion
There are things in primal that come together in just enough amounts to make you not regret buying it but overall, i feel the vast majority of the games gameplay is very repetitive and that lets it down. Despite this when it works, its works really nice !!

And i have yet too discover any major bugs/issues playing this game, but after a few hours of playing the map starts to lag but exiting and restarting the game often elivates this issue.

My Computer Specs
AMD FX 6300 (6core) @ 3.50 GHz, nvidia GTX 960, 8GB DDR3

Runs on Ultra with no shadows @ 50-60fps

reviewText: One of the main complaints I've seen about this game are technical difficulties. I have a low-to-med build that runs the newest games passably well; I've not had the slightest speedbump in launching or playing this game for a solid few hours. A lot of the negative reviews seem to have burst forth within hours of the game being released, and I think that's probably why this game now has a 'mixed' rating. I would whole-heartedly encourage anyone to purchase this game.\n\nThe graphics are stunningly beautiful, even on low. I found the game to be extremely immersive; the daytimes are full of life and sunlight, the nighttimes have you breaking out in a sweat everytime you hear a branch snap. I am not a Far Cry fan, but I've had my eye on this game for some time now. Perhaps this game does not appeal so strongly to fans of the franchise, but if you want to be transported to a different world entirely rather than stranded on an island with a bunch of gun-toting psychopaths, just buy the game already.

reviewText:
After seeing so many negative reviews (most of them technical issues or complaints about the lack of innovation), I'd like to write something good about this game.

1. If you consider it as a FPS survival/crafting game, you should have a lot of fun - it's better than most survival/crafting game out there.  The overall immersion is very good.
2. It has base building - develop your own village, gather villagers and upgrade and watch it grow.
3. The integration of the main story and objectives is better than Far Cry 3 & 4.  In the previous games, I did all the side quests possible, all the hunting, conquered all posts and ran out of things to do before I really got to focus on the campaign.  In this game, I actually look forward to recruit more specialists into my village so I can learn new skills - and that actually move the main story along.

My verdict so far:  9/10

reviewText:
So lets begin with the fact I am NOT a Far Cry franchise fan. I have found the material they have given interesting but then it just seemed to die once you started playing it. Primal however was an interesting twist and caught my attention. I am glad it did.

Primal to me feels like a cross between a solo play version of ArK and a low tech Fallout. The game play has been smooth and just looks great. Did a 3 hour live stream with zero glitches.

Really enjoying the game and have no trouble recommending it to others.

reviewText:
Updated review.

If you enjoyed using the bow more than most of the other weapons in the previous Far Cry games then Primal was made for you! You get 3 bows in this game, and a sling shot. You get spears that you can throw, hell you can throw your one and two handed clubs! Everything can become a projectile in this game, and every weapon can be set on fire! You get throwing bone shards (used in conjunction with stealth kills) some kind of flint throwing shard and a berserk one that just makes people attack their friends, also bee bombs are pretty funny.

I can understand some people have a hard time reading words while watching videos, but as soon as you get out of 5th grade it becomes a non-issue.
Despite the language barrier, the facial animations and hand uses are really well done. The inflection it gives to what you're reading works really well and a lot of these characters will be more memorable than previous FC characters (except Vaas, Hoyt and Pagan Min, do you remember any of the other characters names? No Googling!)

The world is incredible, I've seen evidence that this is the FC4 Map just repurposed. I have also seen a girl I refused to go to prom with who turned into a drool inducing bombshell a decade later. The map is beautiful, it's actually dense, it feels like a forest, and looks like a forest. It's going to win best forest simulator 2016 no doubt. If you enjoy the idea of nature, but don't actually like going outside this game is for you! No sunburn, bug bites, or allergies in this game.

I'm 18 hours in so far, says 44% done, maxed practically every thing, but now I have Master Hunts to do which looks like I may get legendary animals to tame/ride. The quality you get in this game, plus that it looks to be decently long (I hate games I can beat in a day, eat it Lara) make me feel my purchase was worth it. Plus I've never beat a FC game only once, so I will spend plenty of time with this. I hope this review was helpful to some of you, may the spirits guide you Wenja!

I didn't have any issues with running the game.  I have everything on High with 51-34 FPS, 3.5 quad, 16gig ram, 2gig AMD card, anti-aliasing SMAA. I did turn off motion blur because....F motion blur.

reviewText: Far Cry: The Primal Revenant
voteText: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Far Cry PrimalFar Cry Primal is an action-adventure video game.  The game is not a sequal to Far Cry 4.  The game is developed and produced by Ubisoft.


StoryI really have enjoyed the story so far.  The game is set in 10,000 BC, during the beginning of the Mesolithic and Epipaleolithic periods.  Players take on the role of a lone surviving hunter, Takkar, who makes his way to Oros and sets out to build his own tribe.  Takkar learns to tame animals in his quests.  He eventually rises to power and leads his tribe.

I should note that the game is in subtitles for the fictional language used.  At first I was not too enthused about the use of subtitles, but after playing the game I really did not mind.  Although I have to argue that by taking on the role of Takkar, I shouldn't need subtitles to understand what I am saying.

The game is designed with difficulty levels in mind.  The April 12 patch to Primal has introduced Survivor Mode for those that want something much more difficult to play.  Elements, stamina fatigue, permadeath for trained beasts, more difficult taming process for the stronger beasts, skill trees reworked for difficulty, and the option for permadeath for your character.

CraftingThe crafting system is very similiar to Far Cry 4.  The system is easy and in no way overwhelming.  It is simplistic yet ample enough to provide plenty of items such as weapons, equipment, medical items, and food to help you through your adventures or Oros.  Players must craft weapons using the materials scavenged while playing such as wood and stone.

ControlsThe gameplay feels very familiar to anyone who has played Far Cry 3 or 4.  The controls work very well with most keys able to be bound. I could not bind my Cap Locks Lock key which was disappointing but I think I can manage another bind.  The player can dirrectly control the owl which beocme a very useful tool to scout enemies.  Transitioning into the animal controls is fluid and works well.  The owl feels very similiar to flying a helo in FC 4.  The gameplay is very smooth and I really do not have any complaints with the controls, at least in terms of using a keyboard and mouse.

GraphicsFC Primal was built on the Dunia 2 Engine which was used for Far Cry 3 (2012), Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon (2013), Far Cry 4 (2014), and now Far Cry Primal (2016).  While the engine looks good, it is dated and the visuals suffer for it.  Although aestheticly pleasing in many ways, the enviromental fidelity suffers as does the character models.  Why Ubisoft did not pass the AnvilNext 2.0 game engine which Assassin's Creed Unity (2014), Assassin's Creed Syndicate (2015), Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Siege (2015), and For Honor (2016) are built on or perhaps even the Snowflake Engine which Tom Clancy's The Division is built on is dumbfounding.

The game initially had no SLI/Crossfire support.  My fps would double if I force my system to run on a single GTX 980 rather than in tripple SLI.  The patches and Nvidia drivers have resolved this issue, although there is not true sli support that benefits using multiple cards.  But at least sli is now running as good as a single card.

The April 12 patch introduces a HD texture pack for those that want to run Primal on Ultra & 4k.

RecommendationI really enjoy playing Far Cry Primal and do recommend it if you are a fan of the series, even with the changes such as the time period, weapons, and the lack of vehicles the game stands on its own and is very satisfying to play.

Gameplay Videohttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=636325142

Performance Benchmarkhttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=636403600

reviewText:
First off, at the time of writing the reviews for this game stand at Positive (1,346) Negative (695) - Mixed. This is misleading because most of the negative reviews reflect frustration over technical issues at launch. I experienced none whatsoever, and I understand that there appeared several solutions to problems presented.

That being said the game deserves a solid 8/10. It is very similar to other Far Cry games, yet it differs from Far Cry 4 more than Far Cry 4 differs from Far Cry 3. It stands out from the series in a few key ways. The setting takes center stage here, from the language, the flora and fauna, everything feels very primeval. Folks may miss the gunplay, but I found that combat can be very fast and deadly once you realize that many of your weapons are better thrown than used for melee. It is a bummer that there is no block or counter feature to combat, but if you play it right, there is never a need to. With beast in tow, there are plenty of opportunities for melee takedowns, a signature of the series. At least half the combat comes from and between the beast population, which is far more dense and deadly than in previous installments. I also like the improvements to the crafting system. Now that all your weapons can be thrown or are single use, it behooves you to keep well stocked in supplies to craft said weapons. In other Far Cry games I was let down a little in that crafting extended to only about half the game, after I crafted all my bags. Resources and crafting are more relevant thoughout the playthrough now.

All in all, very competently made. It is not ground breaking, but it is more than just Far Cry 4.5 like Blood Dragon was to 3. I would suggest, however waiting for a sale, as it is more of a $30-40 title. No regets here though.

On a side note, I know how frustrating it can be when your purchased software doesn't work properly, but that is why there is a refund system. Seeing the bad reviews leads people to believe that the product is inferior, which isn't the whole truth. I wouldn't say that a movie was bad if I was locked out of the theater. But I would get a refund and complain directly to management. Condemning the hard working artists and coders for the DRM policy of their bosses is unfair.

reviewText:
I feel pretty conflicted about this game, but I'm slightly leaning towards saying yes for recommendation.

The essential game mechanicals hasn't changed too much from Far Cry 4, but has added a few new elements to the game such as beast taming and having a beast side kick. These altered the gameplay quite a bit, it's definitely worth at least trying the game for what's new.

Because the game takes place in 10,000 BCE, classic far cry features such as vehicles and firearms are obviously not present. This is pretty bothersome for me, as you are now required to run from place to places across the maps. Although the game now has a lot of outposts/fast travel checkpoints, this is still quite tedious. You can unlock a skill that lets you ride your larger beasts, but that's not unlocked until quite a few hours into the gameplay typically.  I'm also not a huge fan of non-firearm type weapons such as spears, arrows, and clubs, but they can still work somewhat well after practicing for a bit. Although the game has tons of main missions available, the overall story and plot development is a bit lacking to me.

Overall, I'd say buy the game when it's discounted on sales. The gameplay can get quite boring pretty fast for a lot of players who aren't big on stone age weapons, but it's still definitely fun to play for a few hours at the very least. The game may seem boring at first, but it gets more fun when you've added more citizens to your village.

reviewText:
At this point, I cannot recommend this game at all.  While I do agree the story-line is very simple and the game is made long by discoveries and simple quests, I can look past that short-coming... I have experienced more crashes in a game series which renders the game unplayable as several critical quests are virtually impossible to complete and crashes are disruptive to the storyline.  I have the kind of computer system that handles games like Witcher III without a catch and my bios and drivers are update date - there should be NO REASON for the crashes save poor game testing.

reviewText:
I was blown away the first time i exit the cave, felt like i actually found a new home and will build my new life in Oros now. Its pretty rare for me to get this hooked up by first 15-20 minutes of the game, i considered it very promising start.
Atmosphere in this game is amazing, from beautiful rich nature setting and absolutely stunning visuals to sound engine and voice/face acting.  I havent finished the story yet but got to say it delivers, with some pretty deep cut scenes and turns. Animations and actror/models work are very good, makes you feel and understand what those cave folks felt and what they went thru almost every day. Great job devs!

Lots of people told me that leap from modern day weapons to club and bow is too controvercial, but i got to say that for me its native and actually closer to Far Cry genre now, because now hunting actually makes sence and fits the picture. It was pretty hard for me to be immersed in game when you got to hunt kill Rhino lets say with C4 or RPG.

I had no problems with pre-ordering or starting the game, and actually bought two of them now PS4 and PC versions. I would say this game very well optimized from the start! With this kind of visuals and PostFX 1080/30fps for PS4 is rarity nowdays (rememder AC:Unity) and PC version running smooth and beautiful 40-60fps with everything on Ultra + MSAA at 3440x1440 on my LG 21:9 display (immersive as hell btw) with single EVGA Nvidia Titan X. Again good job folks!

So i do recommend this game very much, even cared enough to put half and hour for this review ;)

| i5 3.4/8Gb RAM/SSD/Titan X 12Gb, Win10 64bit |

reviewText: This might be my favorite farcry yet so far And I love me some farcry. 10,000 BC is a dangerous place... especially at night. Has a real survival kind of feel without all the building b.s. of resource gathering crafting games (so sick of that). The world is gorgeous, the wildlife interactive, the humans are savage, and the controls and mechanics are smooth and fluid. When I pick up this game, I really feel like I am in an adventure in another world. I want to explore everywhere but I must temper that with how dangerous the world is. reviewText:
I've seen a bunch of negative reviews on this game, but I think it's really great.

Animal companions


Cons:

Male only storyline

No Character customization

I wish there was a co-op mode, but I knew there wasn't one when I bought it so I don't feel it should lose points for that.

Overall, it's a really great single player game and I think it's worth buying.  I have never played any of the other Far Cry games, so I can't compare this one to them.

10/10

reviewText: This game has been getting quite a few bad reviews, but I personally really enjoyed this game. There are no guns like the previous Farcry games, which I actually like more than I thought I would. Having to take careful aim with your spears and bow is great... The story isnt as long as say... Farcry 3's, but there are tons of things to do just like FC3 and FC4. At 22 hours into this game, I just hit 43% completion and there is still alot to do on my map.

reviewText:
To preface; I will say that this is not a full review of Far Cry Primal, rather this is an overview. I am doing this because.. I feel that too many people are giving this game a negative review wihout much or any substance objectively. That and in the three or three and a half hours of plaaytime, I found this to be a very fun game, it is exciting and it is entralling. I would aactually like to see Ubisoft experrment more with different time periods, eras. And I feel that people who on the fence should know that this is worth the $60 price tag. I'll update this after I have completed the game, as some things may change. I'm sure I will develop criticisms over the course of the game, etc.. I will not mention anything about the story yet, because I have not progressed far enough into the story. The character animations and VO work that I have experienced so far is convincing and is outstanding work.

So, what makes Primal so captivating, I'll tell you. The setting in itself is one of the major reasons. The world of Oros is beautiful, full of life and is a sensory overload when it comes to the audio; a good thing. Teaming with wildlife and, yes other cavemen. Depite its beauty, this world that has been created is dangerous. You can find yourself into some serious trouble in Oros very quickly! The weapons are primitive and they do lack complex or cool looking animations, but you're a caveman, you're just trying to survive. When attacked and under stress, with your aderline pumping, and a lack of formal training, you are going to swing your club as wildly as possible, and a spear is a thrusting weapon, not a slashing weapon. You're not a highly-trained martial-artist wielding a staff or or a sword. With that said the combat is brutal and fun! That's what matters! It is satisfying to throw a spear into a mans face as it is into an animal, same thing with clubing someone to death. The hunting is great fun! I enjoy the fact how I have to track whatever game I have shot with my bow or thrown spear, because as someone who actually hunts, animals don't just drop dead on the spot most of the time. It's a nice change to see in a game. Many have complained of the partially made up language. Ubisoft did work with experts to craft a language that would be believable, though not 100% accurate. You can hear the emotions converyed through the voice actors and I appluad this apporach. The subtitles do not bother and it adds another layer of immserion to a game that very atmospheric. There is no other game, that I know of that has a wrold like Oros. It is unique in that regard, even if Ark has a world similar. In Ark you have firearms, which to me would detract from the experience overall.

I will recommend to everyone to play on expert" difficulty and to turn most
date: if not all of your HUD elements off. You'll rely pretty much solely on audio cues and it'll take a while
recommended: but you will feel scared and you should feel that thrill
hoursPlayed: that anxiety. Of both being scared and exploring a land you know nothing of. Get out there and get lost
voteText: feel the experience and bask in the atmosphere! You are not at the top of the food-chain
helpfulPercent: you're far from it. I find myself
votesHelpful: especailly at night
votesTotal: which is so much different from the dynamics of daytime play
votesFunny: always being cautious and listening very carefully to sounds. As well as hunting for animals that appear at night only. I am having as close to a caveman experience as I think we may ever get in a AAA title. And this experience feels authentic
commentsCount: as far as video games go. This game as is so far in my experience gets a solid recommendation.\n\nEDIT: Having played more of the game

reviewText:
Writing this review at 9.4 hours in. So far I have really enjoyed the game. All I'm gonna talk about are the elements of the gameplay. It isn't very inovative gameplay wise, but they took a big risk by making a FPS, in a way, set in the stone age. I think the lack of guns make it challenging. Far Cry is Far Cry after all, the usual running around and taking outposts for towers to take over an area. The set amount of resources you can carry does make the crafting interesting. You have to run around and search for different sources in different areas of the map to upgrade your village huts, weapons, resource bags, etc. The resource hunting is endless. The hunting is a bit more challenging because of the limited amounts of weapons you have. To move to different areas you must upgrade your weapons and clothing to be able to survive against harsher elements and the dangerous animals in the different enviroments. The map is a nice size although I haven't explored all of it yet. The missions aren't too mindblowing but they provide entertainment.

If you want a game that will change your life, this isn't it. If you just want a game to entertain yourself until something different comes out, or something to keep the boredom away, then this would be a great game. I can't say anything about the crashes because I haven't experienced any of those yet. It has been fun. Wait for a sale and then pick it up.

In the end the game is entertaining and will keep you busy running around hunting, doing missions, side objectives, and resource gathering. Buy it or don't buy it. Watch some gameplay first. With the whole steam refund thing it makes it much easier to buy a game and try it out. I give it a 7 outta 10. Not the most amazing game I have played but definitely something different. The whole stone age thing really is a cool idea and it would be interesting to see if other developers try it out. Sorry for the long read.

reviewText:
I'll start out by saying the game is gorgeous visually, but what else would you expect from this series.  The major problem I've had so far is not being able to distinguish friend from foe at a distance.  The animal skins work too well as camouflage and everything becomes a jumbled mess unless you're already aiming and let the cross-hair tell you what you're about to shoot.  Yes that is part of the challenge of the game but it can still be annoying to not know there's an enemy around until the gauge that alerts you to being spotted flashes on the screen.

The audio is excellent.  You really get the feeling that you're the one being hunted in Oros, partially because the animals never seem to shut up around you and it becomes a challenge determining which noise means food and which growl means you're about to be food.

Menu interface is counter-intuitive, the same as the other far cry games. The weapon wheel could benefit from being more simplified, and the crafting / character perk menus are overcrowded with icons that are just a tad too small to be useful.  Honestly I don't have a problem scrolling on a perk tree menu if it means I get a little more detail without having to select each individual icon and read it's description.

Traveling can be slow but fast travel is available when you're ready to start hacking away at the game, and there's an actual reward system for helping other people during escort / rescue sidequests so you'll be less likely to ignore their cries for help.

Really, Far Cry Primal is solid, and the complaints I have are in no way deal breakers.  The experience is unique and will more than make up for the game's few flaws.

(Played for 2 hours with X360 Gamepad.  No issues on startup. one crash at the 90 minute mark)

reviewText:
Far Cry Primal is an excellent game. Just getting out in the wilderness and heading in a random direction to see what happens. There are so many random events occurring in the world and they have actually bolted on a very good AI driving the actions of the humans and animals. Ubisoft have done an amazing job. I've turned off almost all player UI aids in the game (this is a must IMO) and it delivers a very immersive experience. I am still trying to tame a sabre tooth. It is difficult. :)

The sound engine is superb. Night time reminds me of the nail biting suspense of Dying Light nights. Night is also the domain of predators.

It's exactly what I want in a Far Cry game and I hope the next iteration of the series builds on the technology and gameplay they have added to Primal.

A huge Thumbs Up!

reviewText:
I've been playing for over 10 hours now and would definitely recommend this game. I've found that sound is very important in the game because sometimes my vision is blocked by grass/bushes/etc, even with hunter vision. I've had a bear get me twice now because I didn't see or hear it. And outrunning them is a joke. They'll catch up and rip you apart unless you kill them.
Fire is your friend. Lots of predators are afraid of the fire and will keep a safe distance until they see an opportunity. Your tamed animal is another deterrent for some predators.
I like how they really tried to be realistic with the wolves and how they hunt. They're always in packs and they use tactics to try and attack you. I've had it where one has rushed me so that my focus is on that one then 2 others flank me while the first runs to a safe distance. It's also kind of sad that if they run, they'll come back and howl for their fallen wolves. Also, their eyes reflect the light at night which is just awesome.

There's definitely some things that they need to work on with the tamed beasts. Sometimes my beast will be stuck somewhere while I'm getting my butt kicked by enemies. Other times, my beast won't disengage from enemies so it ends up dying because it won't come back for me to heal it. It's a bit annoying and frustrating, especially when you're trying to take a bonfire...but it's not a deal breaker.
Yes, it's annoying that they speak a different language and you have to read the subtitles...but you get used to it after a while.
The graphics aren't bad...but they're also not the best. I'm also running it on high". I could probably run it higher than that
date: but it doesn't really matter to me. Again
recommended: not a deal breaker.\n\nThere's plenty to do in the game to keep you occupied. Right now I'm just capturing various bonfires and hunting/gathering so I can upgrade my camp."

reviewText:
First of all for all the people downrating it because of a uPlay DRM authentication error is not a review of the game so please don't down rate it because of that.  To actually review a game you must play it first.  You have no business writing a review of a game you haven't played.  Yes, uPlay sucks and probably will continue to do so until Ubisoft gets smart and uses Steam.

Pros:

The visuals in the game are great it really does feel like a perhistoric land.
The interaction with environment is great.
The crafting system is awesome I actually have to make my own arrows for my bow and in order to do that I have to gather the required materials.
The material gathering for huts and other upgrades seems somewhat realistic you don't have to get a ton of materials.
The language that they developed is amazing.  Props to Ubisoft for that one.
Character visuals are pretty realistic the faces have so much detail and the hair styles seem like what they would be during that era.
Inventory management has greatly improved from previous games I don't have to micromanage anymore.
I could go on but its minor detail stuff.

Cons:

It needs to be optimized occasional hangs and crashes (to be expected just after release honestly).
As with all Far Cry games its resource heavy so it isn't for the feint of heart machines.  Not really con though.
The save mechanic seems to be glitchy is only saving at checkpoints not when you tell it to.

Final thoughts:

This game is for people who like survival this is a hunter gatherer type game as it was during that era.  If you like to shoot things up and blow things up prepare to be dissapointed this is a survival game.  If you like survival games this game is for you but if you are mainly a shooter type give it some thought before you purchase.

reviewText: A LOT of the reviews are from people who haven't played it at all due to error messages and problems loading in, which is weird since it's kind of unfair to review a game you haven't played yet.  This is exactly what I expected, Far Cry in 10,000 BCE.  Good and somewhat understandable villains, in that their motives while not exactly sound, do make a bit of a twisted kind of sense.  Granted it takes time to get to that point because they aren't as quickly shown as they were in 3 and 4.  Taming animals is fun, and scavenger hunting for special items to upgrade your items is always fun to me.  I prefered the twin sided upgrade system since it made more linear sense to me, but this one is far more fleshed out and allows you to more specifically decide what you want to do as your character.  All in all a good game, I'd give it a 8.5/10 from where I am right now in the game, seems like it could go up from where I am since I haven't gotten all around the world yet.

reviewText:
Finally someone decided to break from making generic shooter #378B and tried something new.

Story is pretty good, more or less what you would expect from a Far Cry but set in 10,000 BC. Your tribe traveled to new lands, but the warrior cannibals (there are a few other factions but those are the main bad guy so far) in those lands killed most of them. You are a warrior who got separated from your tribe and has to try and reuinite your scattered people in the new village you start.

So now you have a village that you can upgrade and grow. You not only upgrade your cave and other's huts, you have to find new people who will bring their unique skills to their village and give you new unlocks (I.E. Bring the warrior guy in to unlock new takedowns, bring the crafting guy in to unlock new gear, bring the hunting girl in to get new bows, etc). It's a well done feature that also breaks your skill tree into different blocks for each new (important) person you bring into your village. Theres also a lot of different skills and craftables now. Haven't counted but it sure feels like WAY more than FC4.

The combat is very fun. Basically the same as FC3/FC4 but without the guns. You use clubs, bows and spears to kill your enemies aside from the beasts you can tame. Each weapon has its own unique takedown animations instead of always using your knife.

There's also a day/night cycle ala Dying Light. At night, more predators and certain more rare animals come out, some of these night animal's skins are needed for crafting or missions. I approve of day/night cycles simply for the (relative) realism, but it doesn't change too much in gameplay from what ive seen. Predators are still easy to avoid or kill for the most part (save bears, do NOT ♥♥♥♥ with bears until you have a few upgrades)

Hunting is much more fun now. Instead of a camera you have hunter vision" which
date: rather than tagging enemies (thats a skill you unlock) it will highlight enemies/animals in your FoV. It also highlights animals blood. So if you hit a deer in the leg and it takes off
recommended: now you can just follow the blood trail to the animals body since it will bleed out in a minute.\n\nI like the new map as well. Large with lots of variance in terrain
hoursPlayed: the ambient sounds of all the animals are great. Sometimes you'll stumble upon a pack of wolves chasing after deer
voteText: or a bear fighting a group of Udam (the warrior cannibals you fight). Some people have said it's the same as FC4's map based on where the water is
helpfulPercent: even if they did use the old map as a foundation to build on it feels very different. Lots more vegetation
votesHelpful:
way more variances in elevation so you can sneak around above/below enemies.

The whole north half of the map is also covered in snow and can be very risky to go into early on. You get a "cold meter" when there that decreases until you die. You can either run from campfire to campfire to stay warm or upgrade your clothes so your cold meter goes down more slowly.

Also runs very well
votesTotal: I've had no issues with crashing and with everything maxed get a stable 40-60 fps with few to no dips. Also has a FoV slider that goes all the way up to 120 (something a lot of AAA games somehow miss)\n\nA solid next step (or first step?) in the Far Cry series. The gameplay isn't too much different from FC4 aside from the lack of guns (you still have some of the same animations for manual healing
votesFunny: you have a primitive grapple hook
commentsCount: etc.) But the new setting combined with the lack of guns adds a whole new feel to Far Cry. The characters are all interesting with their own reasons for hating the Udam and the gameplay is enjoyable."

reviewText:
Not having any issues what so ever, not a single crash and everything runs at a good framerate, others are having issues tho so bear that in mind.

Unfortunate that he rallied everyone to bury the game, which hurts sales when Ubisoft finally make something interesting, but oh well what can you do.

Anyway, unpopular opinion, but the Far Cry team tried something (semi) new and i think it's great. The nature feels real, the animals feel alive, hunting is interesting and taming didn't turn out to be a bad gimmic afterall. I'm loving being a caveman.

reviewText:
Writing this review at 9.4 hours in. So far I have really enjoyed the game. All I'm gonna talk about are the elements of the gameplay. It isn't very inovative gameplay wise, but they took a big risk by making a FPS, in a way, set in the stone age. I think the lack of guns make it challenging. Far Cry is Far Cry after all, the usual running around and taking outposts for towers to take over an area. The set amount of resources you can carry does make the crafting interesting. You have to run around and search for different sources in different areas of the map to upgrade your village huts, weapons, resource bags, etc. The resource hunting is endless. The hunting is a bit more challenging because of the limited amounts of weapons you have. To move to different areas you must upgrade your weapons and clothing to be able to survive against harsher elements and the dangerous animals in the different enviroments. The map is a nice size although I haven't explored all of it yet. The missions aren't too mindblowing but they provide entertainment.

If you want a game that will change your life, this isn't it. If you just want a game to entertain yourself until something different comes out, or something to keep the boredom away, then this would be a great game. I can't say anything about the crashes because I haven't experienced any of those yet. It has been fun. Wait for a sale and then pick it up.

In the end the game is entertaining and will keep you busy running around hunting, doing missions, side objectives, and resource gathering. Buy it or don't buy it. Watch some gameplay first. With the whole steam refund thing it makes it much easier to buy a game and try it out. I give it a 7 outta 10. Not the most amazing game I have played but definitely something different. The whole stone age thing really is a cool idea and it would be interesting to see if other developers try it out. Sorry for the long read.

Probably the best thing about this game is the controls feel just as smooth whether you're playing with a controller or the keyboard/mouse, which is an often overlooked feature, and I love they put the extra effort into it.


All in all, 8/10, if you liked Fallout 4, give this a shot, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Far Cry Primal is an excellent game. Just getting out in the wilderness and heading in a random direction to see what happens. There are so many random events occurring in the world and they have actually bolted on a very good AI driving the actions of the humans and animals. Ubisoft have done an amazing job. I've turned off almost all player UI aids in the game (this is a must IMO) and it delivers a very immersive experience. I am still trying to tame a sabre tooth. It is difficult. :)

The sound engine is superb. Night time reminds me of the nail biting suspense of Dying Light nights. Night is also the domain of predators.

It's exactly what I want in a Far Cry game and I hope the next iteration of the series builds on the technology and gameplay they have added to Primal.

A huge Thumbs Up!

reviewText:
I've been playing for over 10 hours now and would definitely recommend this game. I've found that sound is very important in the game because sometimes my vision is blocked by grass/bushes/etc, even with hunter vision. I've had a bear get me twice now because I didn't see or hear it. And outrunning them is a joke. They'll catch up and rip you apart unless you kill them.
Fire is your friend. Lots of predators are afraid of the fire and will keep a safe distance until they see an opportunity. Your tamed animal is another deterrent for some predators.
I like how they really tried to be realistic with the wolves and how they hunt. They're always in packs and they use tactics to try and attack you. I've had it where one has rushed me so that my focus is on that one then 2 others flank me while the first runs to a safe distance. It's also kind of sad that if they run, they'll come back and howl for their fallen wolves. Also, their eyes reflect the light at night which is just awesome.

There's definitely some things that they need to work on with the tamed beasts. Sometimes my beast will be stuck somewhere while I'm getting my butt kicked by enemies. Other times, my beast won't disengage from enemies so it ends up dying because it won't come back for me to heal it. It's a bit annoying and frustrating, especially when you're trying to take a bonfire...but it's not a deal breaker.
Yes, it's annoying that they speak a different language and you have to read the subtitles...but you get used to it after a while.
The graphics aren't bad...but they're also not the best. I'm also running it on high". I could probably run it higher than that
date: but it doesn't really matter to me. Again
recommended: not a deal breaker.\n\nThere's plenty to do in the game to keep you occupied. Right now I'm just capturing various bonfires and hunting/gathering so I can upgrade my camp."
