reviewText:
To preface; I will say that this is not a full review of Far Cry Primal, rather this is an overview. I am doing this because.. I feel that too many people are giving this game a negative review wihout much or any substance objectively. That and in the three or three and a half hours of plaaytime, I found this to be a very fun game, it is exciting and it is entralling. I would aactually like to see Ubisoft experrment more with different time periods, eras. And I feel that people who on the fence should know that this is worth the $60 price tag. I'll update this after I have completed the game, as some things may change. I'm sure I will develop criticisms over the course of the game, etc.. I will not mention anything about the story yet, because I have not progressed far enough into the story. The character animations and VO work that I have experienced so far is convincing and is outstanding work.

So, what makes Primal so captivating, I'll tell you. The setting in itself is one of the major reasons. The world of Oros is beautiful, full of life and is a sensory overload when it comes to the audio; a good thing. Teaming with wildlife and, yes other cavemen. Depite its beauty, this world that has been created is dangerous. You can find yourself into some serious trouble in Oros very quickly! The weapons are primitive and they do lack complex or cool looking animations, but you're a caveman, you're just trying to survive. When attacked and under stress, with your aderline pumping, and a lack of formal training, you are going to swing your club as wildly as possible, and a spear is a thrusting weapon, not a slashing weapon. You're not a highly-trained martial-artist wielding a staff or or a sword. With that said the combat is brutal and fun! That's what matters! It is satisfying to throw a spear into a mans face as it is into an animal, same thing with clubing someone to death. The hunting is great fun! I enjoy the fact how I have to track whatever game I have shot with my bow or thrown spear, because as someone who actually hunts, animals don't just drop dead on the spot most of the time. It's a nice change to see in a game. Many have complained of the partially made up language. Ubisoft did work with experts to craft a language that would be believable, though not 100% accurate. You can hear the emotions converyed through the voice actors and I appluad this apporach. The subtitles do not bother and it adds another layer of immserion to a game that very atmospheric. There is no other game, that I know of that has a wrold like Oros. It is unique in that regard, even if Ark has a world similar. In Ark you have firearms, which to me would detract from the experience overall.

I will recommend to everyone to play on expert" difficulty and to turn most
date: if not all of your HUD elements off. You'll rely pretty much solely on audio cues and it'll take a while
recommended: but you will feel scared and you should feel that thrill
hoursPlayed: that anxiety. Of both being scared and exploring a land you know nothing of. Get out there and get lost
voteText: feel the experience and bask in the atmosphere! You are not at the top of the food-chain
helpfulPercent: you're far from it. I find myself
votesHelpful: especailly at night
votesTotal: which is so much different from the dynamics of daytime play
votesFunny: always being cautious and listening very carefully to sounds. As well as hunting for animals that appear at night only. I am having as close to a caveman experience as I think we may ever get in a AAA title. And this experience feels authentic
commentsCount: as far as video games go. This game as is so far in my experience gets a solid recommendation.\n\nEDIT: Having played more of the game
column16: I feel that the story is good enough so far. It's not top tier
column17: it is not The Witcher 3 calibre of story-telling; but it is not a bad story. What is most important that I've realized is that now that I have tamed most of the beasts

reviewText:
One big aspect of this game being a great time is that you have all the makings for a story of your own. Yep, role-playing. Not using shortcuts, taking everything off the UI on screen, already you'll find the game more interesting. Now, decide to only play as realistically as you would if you were there. You wouldn't stand in the middle of their camp and hope to shoot them all first. I get the Owl out, recce ahead, plan my moves two or three ahead. I find the outter enemies of an encampment or whatever the best to pick off first, just as I would in real life. I summon my stealthest beast.   The stragglers get eaten without out any alarms.   You know what Im getting at. This game is a fantastic open canvas of how ever you like to play. I was about to refund this game, but I decided to try realistic style approach.  No helps, no exploits, no cheesy running in and taking your chances. You wouldn't do that in real life. But in this game does it ever bring in the suspension of disbelief.

Give it a good try. The game becomes all that you wished it would do for you. But this is a game you play close to the bone, and it comes alive. I'm 24% through, and 30 hours into it. I have 3/4 of a game left, and I'm already not wanting it to end.  There is just so much you can do in this game, but it will take a choice on your part. Are you willing to put a bit of effort into it, or moan, because the Dev's have left something out that you feel makes the game poor.  Not a chance, This is a polished, smooth running, innovative aspects of stealth, pet taming, etc. Brilliant. Can't wait to see where this goes.

Developer's, thanks you for a wonderful labour of love youve put into your game. The details prove that over and over, that this game shines, and its ready for prime-time gameplay, for me anyway.

Of course, ymmv.  But give it a good shot, before you give up on it.

reviewText:

Negatives

Hopefully this game gets more appreciated for what it is getting

reviewText:
If you're interested in a great game that you want to immerse yourself in and  take your time and enjoy, primal will provide you with that oppourtunity.
Your average COD kid is probably the reason there are so many poor reviews of this game. It is a great game just not for everyone.
Its not a shooter, its more of a stealth/exploration game with a healthy dose of hunting and crafting thrown into the mix. It's not grindy, contrary to what I had read before buying it. Those reviewers must have the attention span of an 8 year old. Seriously I'm not kidding.
Ubisoft has done a great job of bringing their vision of 10 000 bc to life, complete with the spoken languages of the inhabitants and a living, breathing world teeming with life. You can almost smell the fresh, unpolluted air blowing down off that giant glacier hanging on the distant mountains.
All the boohooing about the shape of the map matching farcry 4. Don't worry, This is a complete new world to explore. I put alot of time into Farcry 4 and if I hadn't read about the map thing I would have never known. This is a lush beautiful, orginal world to spend some time in.
I don't miss the guns. I actually feel alot more relaxed in Oros, honestly its kinda freeing. There are enough upgrades for the available clubs, bows, spears etc that it is keeping it interesting enough for me.
Besides you can ride a sabertooth tiger what the hell else can a guy ask for. They had me the first time I speared an enemy from the back of my sabertooth.

reviewText: FIRST OF ALL!!!! The map is WAY different than FarCry4. The river layout is similar, however the topography is INSANELY different! The combat is more challenging i feel, since there's no more guns, and thats a plus for me! Taming animals could have been made a bit more of a challenge, but I'm not complaining. I still have a ways to go in the story, but definitely a lot more dependent on scavenging, and gathering resources. I recommend it, and I thoroughly enjoy it!\n11/10 would get stomped by a mammoth again

reviewText:
Pros:
- The idea is really good. I was looking forward for it.
- The graphics are ok for me; probally they should have made the possibility for higher graphic settings.
- Also the  fire is cool. Unfortunately you can't really burn down the enemy villages; you can put them on fire but this    doesn't change a lot. Even in missions where you need to burn down things these things will respawn.
- Stroy has good basic approaches, but there could have been done much more.
- Language is interesting. But again, there would have been MUCH more potential.
- enviroment looks nice and interesting

Cons:

The game is much too easy: The beast taming is incredible easy, you can get a cave lion in the first few hours of the game, even on hardest difficulty. And if you have one you will have no trouble at all anymore, because then you have in short time ALL beasts. You can run through the country with your cat following you scaring and killing everyone you meet while collecting everything you see on the minimap, so that your village is fully upgraded after 10 hours of game play.

It has nothing to do with survival:
- no starvation etc
- healing too easy; beast revival too (even if the beast is killed in battle you can run to it, give it 3 meat and it will have full health again)
- your population can only grow (even if you see your people dying by a enemy attack. Population is only reduced by teamkills)
- too much population on close room (bascially every 10m a enemy patrol etc)
- beast taming is a joke: throw a few flesh infront of an cave bear who attacked you 2 seconds ago and be best friends with the cave bear 4 seconds later. You can even kill your animals or put them on fire; they won't hurt you at all if you tamed them once.
- you can use a owl to scout but its the only owl in the whole world
- combat is awful (melee is nothing more than a click orgy; archery is ok though). Beasts will kill everything. You kill a wolf with 1 strike? The enemy warriors of a naturally stronger tribe are murdered 3vs1 by a normal wolf. And I don't even need to say what happens if you have a saberthoot cat...
- Poisonous snakes are a joke. You got bitten by such snake? Eat 3 meats and feel fresh like bevor. Or better: You can find the snake with your x-ray before and give it a headshot with your bow).
- No weather (no storm, winter etc) which makes the life in stone age hard


I played Witcher 3 on god mode and even with invulnerability it was more difficult than Far Cry Primal.
If you want nothing deep and just rush through a game with stone age setting and repeating missions it's perfect for you.
If you expected to travel through a beatiful world without being attacked every 10m by 2-3 enemy warriors (even if you have a saberthoot cat) and hope that this game is more survival and immersive than Far Cry 4 you might be dissappointed.

reviewText:
First The disclaimer: This is an Ubisoft Game. They use the same basic formula with most of there games. Like Assasins Creed, Watch Dogs, Far Cry's.

That said, what makes this one unique is the setting. The year is 10,000BC and your a member of a proto-european tribe called the Wenja. The Wenja have been decimated by rival tribes and you must build it back up again.

Along the way you can become a beast master and train beasts to follow your will.

The game requires you to have uplay and to use the cdkey you get from steam to be used on uplay. after that launching from the steam button automatically launches uplay and the game with out any further interaction an the players part.

I'm aprox. two hours into the game at the time of writting this review and so far this is amazing. I love the setting and that the people speak in a proto-european language (with english subtitles) which I'm quite used too as I watch alot of Anime in Japanese.

The only way it could be better is if there was a stereoscopic mode for 3D play.

I definitely recomend this game.

reviewText:
PRO: You can be a MAMMOTH RIDING SABERTOOTH/CAVE BEAR TAMING STONE AGE MURDERING MANIAC.

CON: LET ME CHANGE MY OWN SETTINGS!


I am not sure why other people had so many problems, I preloaded mine and had no issues whatsoever, even getting above 60 fps, not sure if that has to do with my build or not which I will post in this review. Game released I did the little update and started it right up.

I really enjoy this game, I was burned out after Far Cry 3 and this is a nice refreshing take on the series. I think people are being just a little too pretentious in their reviews thus far, its something different from the normal hey let me just run around and shoot stuff up.

I feel way more vulnerable in this game than I have in awhile, animals and enemies can really sneak up on you if you are too busy enjoying the view, especially if you are in thick brush!

Anyway I would recommend this game but I do understand the frustration of others not being able to boot it up on release day.

The only thing that really pisses me off so far is I can't find a way to change the settings other than changing it from High" to "Ultra" and whenever I do try and change the settings the game either stops responding or just force closes. Not sure what that's about

reviewText:
So its like this my boys, People will say not much has changed, but the brand new fluid melee system is ungodly, its tons of fun smashing stuff.

Pros and Cons Below

TL;DR Lots of cool new stuff, but also some of the same, Its a great game, easy to get immersed. but dont be shocked if you see some recycled farcry in a farcry, Did i pay 60 and regret my choice? Not at all, Ive played for around 8 hours, only 10% done, Tons to do, High production value, Stunning cinematics, Fresh outlook on the farcry series done rather well.

Pros
-NO MORE ♥♥♥♥ING TOWERS TO CLIMB, ♥♥♥♥ THOSE TOWERS.
-Huge map Im not 100% but looks a decent size bigger than farcry 4
-Im 100% bug free
-GRAFIX
-Animals are super usefull, can dumpster multiple enimeies for you, OR you can easily store them away for super stealth missions, Owl is a great addition, hope to see drones in place of owl in future farcrys :)
-Alive world, constant random events
-Bear N ♥♥♥♥ Scary bruh, no cake walks here
-Huge skill trees, deffinetly bigger than previous titles
-Exploring is Infinetly more rewarding, No more searching chests to find condoms and cash, its all useful stuff bro!
-Cold System, Dont freeze to death stone dude!
-Did i mention melee combat was a blast?

Indifferent
- Constant crafting, You can pick up anything you throw or shoot, but they do break rather quickly at low levels, requiring alot of crafting, Crafting itself is easy as pie, 1 button right from your weapon wheel, i guess some poeple might not like the contant prodding of foraging for materials, I find no shortage of them and i find it a welcome addition.

Cons
-Yes this farcry is similar in ways to previous farcrys, but wtf, seriously who didnt expect that buying a farcry game
-Pets need to be sent away for stealth (Not a huge annoying just press a button and theyre gone)
-Alot of running at first, no animal mounts at the start sadly, but its cool they are in there (Obviously youves een pictures of people riding mammoths)
-You may find the caveman AI a little silly, but they dont seem too much more stupid than pagen mins men.

reviewText:
Let me start out by saying that the low end computer user saltiness is REAL ASF
Also, if you get a black screen or the game crashes at the epilepsy warning, make sure your drivers are updated. It worked for me
Finally, i strongly recommend playing this game on expert difficulty with no minimap or reticle
Now for the gameplay
[Pros]
Weapons are limited, however incredibly satisfying to use with multiple upgrades each
You can ride ♥♥♥♥ing sabertooth tigers
Nature is a much more prominent part of this installment, feels very lively
You can ride ♥♥♥♥ing sabertooth tigers
Melee combat is a viable option
Did i mention you can ride ♥♥♥♥ing BEARS TOO
Crafting system is similar to FC4s
You can light spears and clubs on fire to scare off animals at night (A mechanic i love)
Building up your village unlocks new upgrades
MAMOTH RIDING
Animal skins filled with bees are a thing
The game isnt spoken in english, which, for the sake of immersion, is pretty neat
Did i mention you can TAME A DOGGO

[Cons]
All joking aside, the game does have a couple preformance issues. I get screen tearing on occasion and I've had some friends tell me that they have similar issues. Beware of those, but it doesnt ruin the experience at all for me
The games difficulty falls off quickly, which is why i recommend playing it on expert
The game inst spoken in english, which isnt a huge issue for me, but be aware of it if you think itll ruin the dialogue for you
The owls a bit wonky

My final score for this game would probably be an 8/10
it has satisfying combat, a good balance of complexity and simplicity in the crafting system, and a really nice animal taming system that ALLOWS YOU TO RIDE SABERTOOTH TIGERS

reviewText:
There's a lot of negativity in the reviews, and I get it, but I'm not sure it's all entirely justified. Sure, this plays like the recent FC games. But we, the people who pre-ordered or picked this up in the first couple of days must have enjoyed those, right? If you didn't, then why on stoneage-earth would you pay full price when every single trailer, preview stream, and week's worth of console footage showed it was going to be just like the FC3/4? If you're completely new to FC, and just got hooked on the stoneage world and are now suffering issues, then for you I feel genuinely sorry.

So I knew what I was buying, and I love it.

The new setting is both beautiful and terrifying. If you want the experience, switch the UI off, crank the sound up, and just go exploring. As you'd expect, there's a ton of stuff to go see, to hunt, to quest for and to gather. Build your town up, talk to the locals, realise you're picking up words of the language and geeking out over pronouncing the words just right, and admit to yourself this game has sucked you in like its predecessors.

There must be some issues and bugs - so many people are saying so. And it's Day 2 of the PC version, so that's not surprising. Googling around, there's not many hints of confirmed game-breakers, and most (not all) of the complaint reviews here on Steam haven't got enough playtime to have come anywhere close to those. My machine's no powerhouse - it's just a 980 (that I bought for FC4) sitting with an AMD Black from 2015, OC'ed a little, and everything is running at 1080 on maxxed settings - no stutter, no frame-rate drops to anything noticeable, no crashing. Maybe there's issues at 4k, but until my kids have grown a little, that option's not on the table for me, nor for a whole host of other gamers. If it's not running properly on your shinier rig, and you've tweaked all the settings and got nowhere, then go find a way to report it. They will fix it, just probably not today. They want your money, they want you to buy the next game. Just try to be realistic - there's no way of testing a game on even a significant fraction of all the possible machine builds out there, and sorting performance issues can take some time.

Should you buy it? If you're new to the FC series, sure, jump in here and spend a *lot* of time in this world. If you liked FC 3 or 4, and don't mind that this one is kinda the same, but with pets instead of rocket launchers, then again, yup, buy it and enjoy the bits they've done differently as you work your way to becoming the most epic caveman of all time. I'd buy it again in a heartbeat, and I'll be continuing to play it slowly in the few gaps I get these days.

Rock on, cave-dwellers!

reviewText:
I like this game. Some don't, for various reasons, but I do.

I am a big fan of the aesthetics; the looks, the feeling that they've captured. It is truly a beautiful game. I do enjoy the combat as well, especially charging into battle on the back of a Mammoth or a Sabertooth. There is lots to do and it does feel like a Far Cry game set in the stone age.

The game fails however, at presenting you with a clear story, or a sense of purpose or direction. You go through side quests until the story is complete. Some might consider this approach (having the story delievered in a non-linear way) good, but i personally didn't like it. There were some minor graphical bugs that were annoying. Speaking of annoying, forget the Oros is a dangerous place where you aren't on top of the food chain"-thing
date: frequent animal attacks become a huge thorn in your side after a while.\n\nAll in all

reviewText: Although i have only played 9 hours so far the game is amazing !!! much better than expected. Many people have said that it feels like a farcry game in how things and done , and yes it does but it works so well despite no guns and vehicles. The game is really immersive (especially in ultra settings aha) but the graphics are really nice. With breathtaking views and a savage combat style the game really feels truly stone age and really gasps what life may have been like. The game may only have about 10 weapons but its the creative ways in which you can use them which make them all that more special and the fact that you have to craft them makes every arrow and spear throw count ! I highly recomend this game as I have really enjoyed it so far and is a game which makles me want to spend alot of fun houres playing !! :D

reviewText: As a diehard fan of Far Cries 2, 3, and 4, I was a bit skeptical about a Far Cry without guns. But I do love the franchise in general so I gave it a shot. Primal does have its upsides; graphically its beautiful, the storyline is interesting enough, and the gameplay is immediatly familiar to anyone who's played the previous games. That said, I very quickly tired of using nothing but a bow and a handful of melee weapons. Admittedly I haven't played it much at all, but it seems an FPS without any actual shooting just can't hold my interest. Compared to earlier entries in the Far Cry series the combat in Primal is horribly lacking in variety. Had it been made under a different title it might have been less of a let down, but I'm afraid the Far Cry name set expectations that Primal simply can't live up to.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was a little hesitant about buying this game.  I love the time period and the rawness of using more simplistic weaponry, but I was concerned about some of the negative reviews the game was getting. I decided to take the risk and buy it, and I'm so glad I did.
Firstly, the game looks beautiful.  The lighting as you creep through dense jungle through rays of light is just astonishing. As is the volumetric fog and the atmosphere it creates.  The different biomes really do breathe life into the map in a way similar to Skyrim.  I just don't get the irony of all the people who bought Far cry 5 and are complaining that the game is like a far cry game.  The simplistic weapons really add to the crafting system and make the survival element of the game more real than just walking around the map to complete a story.  There's more UI customization in this game than previous ones.  I 've chosen to get rid of all the clutter.  I turned off The minimap, game hints, enemy tagging etc in favour of realism.  The game now feels more like a more advanced stone age Skyrim than a Far Cry game.  Another patch is in the making already to add a survival mode with features such as permadeath and other options, so support is ongoing.
My advice to anyone thinking buying the game, is to ignore negative comments and trust your instincts as I did.  If the nature of the game appeals to you, the simple weapons, the survival elements and the time period, then go for it. I'm sure you won't be disappointed.
People who buy a game set in the stone age, then complain that there are no guns, belong in the stone age.

reviewText:
If you're interested in a great game that you want to immerse yourself in and  take your time and enjoy, primal will provide you with that oppourtunity.
Your average COD kid is probably the reason there are so many poor reviews of this game. It is a great game just not for everyone.
Its not a shooter, its more of a stealth/exploration game with a healthy dose of hunting and crafting thrown into the mix. It's not grindy, contrary to what I had read before buying it. Those reviewers must have the attention span of an 8 year old. Seriously I'm not kidding.
Ubisoft has done a great job of bringing their vision of 10 000 bc to life, complete with the spoken languages of the inhabitants and a living, breathing world teeming with life. You can almost smell the fresh, unpolluted air blowing down off that giant glacier hanging on the distant mountains.
All the boohooing about the shape of the map matching farcry 4. Don't worry, This is a complete new world to explore. I put alot of time into Farcry 4 and if I hadn't read about the map thing I would have never known. This is a lush beautiful, orginal world to spend some time in.
I don't miss the guns. I actually feel alot more relaxed in Oros, honestly its kinda freeing. There are enough upgrades for the available clubs, bows, spears etc that it is keeping it interesting enough for me.
Besides you can ride a sabertooth tiger what the hell else can a guy ask for. They had me the first time I speared an enemy from the back of my sabertooth.

reviewText:
At first I was super excited for another Far Cry game... Was still excited after a few moments of gameplay. I soon realized that the game is actually REALLY boring, the side quests are all the same and the story line is just... bad. With this being 10.000 BC they could've come up with AMAZING interesting storyline but nope..

To say a few good things about this game;
1. It is a gorgeous game to look at, the way the light behaves, the scenery. Beautiful.
2. I liked the tame a beast thing, really cool. Also scouting the area ahead with the owl was pretty handy too.

I would rate this... 4/10. Just because I like a good storyline when I play something. I cannot play this game and not be bored while doing so.

If you still need to play this game, please wait for a decent discount. I regret paying 50€ for this..

reviewText: Awful. In previous years, I reluctantly swallowed Ubisofts 'uplay' game guide - but at least it worked. Today, after spending $85 on a game, which personally I don't consider to be a small amount of money, I am locked out. I am not able to even install this game, because the first thing it does is prompt me for a uplay account. The simple answer would be to make one, but I actually only use one email address, which is already connected to the account, thereby putting me in the same situation. For a company that is so well known, so effective at making big titles, and so shallow as to attach their own third party 'trophy system' (/monitoring app/ theft security/ GARBAGE), I simply expect more. At the very least, I expect that if I clock 'forgot my password', that the provided link takes me to a live website, instead of an 'invalid link'.\nIn saying all this, I'm sure the game is outstanding. But personally speaking, I couldn't say. I just spent nearly one hundred dollars on a f******* title, but not the game that was supposed to come with it.

reviewText: I'm having so much fun with this. This is what the Far Cry engine was made for, and the beastmaster control of animals is amazing. Crafting is fun and challenging, because you're always working your way towards the next upgrade and trying to find the skin and ingredients you need.\nFlying recon with your owl while fire bombing people from above, and directing your sabertooth tiger to attack the panicked crowd never gets old. You take down one fortress after the other, cackling gleefully the whole time.\nThe beastmaster control is so much better than any modern weapons or sniper rifles like in previous games. There's a bit of a story to keep you going, but for the most part you just make your own fun with your ménagère of fierce animal friends.

reviewText:
Not worth it, especially if you played Farcry before... same game different setting and some new features. Played through most of it and got so bored, that it took me 16 days to finally come back and finish it (It would probably be better if the game was a little bit cheaper and shorter, as it wouldn't be giving you time to get bored of it).

I've played Far Cry 3 and skipped Farcry 4, because I thought it would be what this was, basically the same game.

Also some of the new features can be really annoying, like pets alerting the enemies, pets dying all the time, pets being an easy kill against heavy enemies (bears too) and the owl may seem cool at first, but then it's just... meh.

Oh and there's a ton of different weapons, from wich you'll end up using maybe three of them. But you'll certainly need weapons since there's enemy patrols every 50 yards.

...better stop now or I'll just keep remembering other stuff.

reviewText:
8/10 - This is one of my favorite Far Cry games, and I own a bunch including 4 which everyone compares this to, I hated 4.

I think 2015/2016 is Ubisofts year, I loved both the Division and Fary Cry Primal.

I play the game @ 4K Ultra settings and its litterally one of the best looking and sounding games I own.

Very fun gameplay, similar stuff to Far Cry series, but love the different theme. Good Job Ubisoft.

Funny thing is, I am used to FPS games what have a 7 hour campain, and tedius multiplayer grind. You dont see anyone complaining about price on those games. Yet I have ready 30 reviews where people have 30-80 hours played and say its not worth $60.00

Let me tell you something if you get 30 hours out of a game, its worth $60.. period. Witcher 3 quest line can be beated in 19 hours or less, yet people think thats a game worth every penny. I own Witcher 3, and had a lot of fun in Primal.

Good Job Ubisoft! Keep making the cool games!

reviewText:
I will go against all of the negative reviews for Far Cry Primal. Any fan of the Far Cry series should know exactly what they are getting into.

PRO's:
1. Absolutely stunning graphics. Runs flawlessly on my modest rig.
2. Excellent story (so far).
3. Character progression.
4. Time period (who hasn't wanted to be a caveman?)

Cons:
1. No worth it at full price. I picked it up half off so it was a good deal but you should
wait until the price drops.

reviewText:
If you like Farcry for guns and blowing stuff up. You won't like this one.
If you like Farcry for only the alternate endings and story. You might not like this one.
If you enjoy Farcry for its overall gameplay (being on your own against goliath like enemy leaders, starting from nothing and rising to the top in a big open world full of action all over). You'll like this one.
If you like bows. spears, and clubs. You'll like this one.

Overall this game was really fun for me. The story was somewhat dissapointing, but the general gameplay was great.

reviewText:
This is a Far Cry game. It's an open world first person shooter (With bows and spears) set in the year 10,000 BCE. It's got collectibles, outposts to scout out and capture, and bonfires which open up the surrounding map.

By far, the biggest knock against this game is that it is ostensibly too similar to Far Cry 4. However, I never played Far Cry 4 and my last Far Cry game played was Blood Dragon in 2014. It's the proven Far Cry formula and it still works. If you're tired of it, then I suggest you wait until a sale. But, for me, it was worth the price.

Removing the guns from a Far Cry game was a bold step and I welcomed the difference. Combat is closer than the past far cry games since spears and bows don't have the range of a sniper rifle. This change made me have to adapt my usual play style to make it work. I played the game as a pseudo open world stealth game as a result. Sneaking through the night dodging wolves and bears only to chuck a freaking spear into the back of some dudes head and then watching the impact cause him to fly off a cliff was always satisfying. I'm pretty sure I killed 2 guys with the same spear once.

I spent about 40 hours with this game and never got bored with it. I didn't even do every side quest or collectible so if you're a completionist, you can dump a ton of time into this game. The setting was very interesting and the story wrapped up nicely.

Bottom line is that it's a Far Cry game. If you're new to the series, this is an interesting place to start. If you're tired of the formula then maybe wait until you see a sale. But this game isn't as bad as some have said.

reviewText:
alright so i am a major far cry fan, so it costs me to say this

dont buy this game right now. its not worth it. buy it on sale

Pros:
-you really feel like you are in the stone age
-the world feels alive with many animals going around their bussiness, hunting, grazing and going around their lives
-the owl seems cool, although it may become gamebreaking overpower after you get berserker bombs
-many upgrades, although some of them dont do a thing (some lvl 2 huts just give exp bonus, no real reward for the upgrade)

cons:
- stealth is so awful, it might has well not exist at all. you will find yourself many times hidden in a bush at long range at night, and the enemy can still find you like you were has bright has the sun. a srly downfall for a game that rewards stealth
-your pets become a pain in the ♥♥♥ has the game goes over. big blocky hit boxes will block your way on tight caves, they will reveal your position to the enemy by jumping on them without a command and long heal animations gets real old real fast, and you will need to heal them a lot, especially when you want to ride them.
- pets feel very gray, like they were all the same, despite the description, all they do is jump enemies when you dont want to, and die. taming them is easy, throw bait and press E. IMO it would be better if we had a special building  to help tame pets, but no, 2 buttons is enough
- quests degrade has you advance, first quests are awesome and mistic, final quests are go there and kill everyone"

you can still have fun with this game
recommended: you are better off waiting for a sale if you really want this game"

reviewText:
I do not recommed buying this game for its full price.
It is more of an extensive DLC than a standalone triple A title.

It feels like Ubisoft put some thought into the setting and the assets, which are very cool, but the game itself feels so very shallow.
It is full of menial and generic tasks, boring skills and repetitive gathering.
After a few hours it seems like you're already close to the end without the feeling that you actually achieved much.

My impression is that they were content with building a beautiful little sandbox and didn't bother to flesh out some really interesting gameplay.

reviewText:
So far its been a fine game. It may not quite make my price/hour ideal but such is life. Ideally if I can get 1$ per hour on a single player story based game I am quite pleased. FCP looks like ill get away with 2$ per hour.

Yes UPlay can be a pain sometimes get over it. You knew what you were getting into.

I have had 2 crashes in 14 hours of game play its a new game ♥♥♥♥ happens. Had a brief issue with Uplay but that resolved in around 10 mins on Uplay's end. ♥♥♥♥ happens.

For those complaining that the map is recycled I suggest to you that Oros is Kryat in prehistory.  The work they did on making a living world" is well worth looking at a similar map as the one for Kryat. I'm gestimating that the full Oros map is at least 50% larger than Farcry 4 just from what I've seen so far.

The story is fine. Hasn't hooked me like FC3 but I really liked the story for 3. But makes sense and is coherent

Graphics are beutiful on my system. Definately an improvement over FC4. For those having issues I suggest upgrading.

At the end of the day Far Cry Primal is a unique title covering a period that isnt often addressed in video games and is well worth a look."

reviewText:
alright so i am a major far cry fan, so it costs me to say this

dont buy this game right now. its not worth it. buy it on sale

Pros:
-you really feel like you are in the stone age
-the world feels alive with many animals going around their bussiness, hunting, grazing and going around their lives
-the owl seems cool, although it may become gamebreaking overpower after you get berserker bombs
-many upgrades, although some of them dont do a thing (some lvl 2 huts just give exp bonus, no real reward for the upgrade)

cons:
- stealth is so awful, it might has well not exist at all. you will find yourself many times hidden in a bush at long range at night, and the enemy can still find you like you were has bright has the sun. a srly downfall for a game that rewards stealth
-your pets become a pain in the ♥♥♥ has the game goes over. big blocky hit boxes will block your way on tight caves, they will reveal your position to the enemy by jumping on them without a command and long heal animations gets real old real fast, and you will need to heal them a lot, especially when you want to ride them.
- pets feel very gray, like they were all the same, despite the description, all they do is jump enemies when you dont want to, and die. taming them is easy, throw bait and press E. IMO it would be better if we had a special building  to help tame pets, but no, 2 buttons is enough
- quests degrade has you advance, first quests are awesome and mistic, final quests are go there and kill everyone"

you can still have fun with this game
recommended: you are better off waiting for a sale if you really want this game"

reviewText:
I do not recommed buying this game for its full price.
It is more of an extensive DLC than a standalone triple A title.

It feels like Ubisoft put some thought into the setting and the assets, which are very cool, but the game itself feels so very shallow.
It is full of menial and generic tasks, boring skills and repetitive gathering.
After a few hours it seems like you're already close to the end without the feeling that you actually achieved much.

My impression is that they were content with building a beautiful little sandbox and didn't bother to flesh out some really interesting gameplay.

reviewText:
I think this might be my favorite Far Cry so far.

If you like Far Cry games for the inevitable uber-weapons that you can get, so that you can start slaughtering the countryside with ease, this might not be the Far Cry for you. Your primary ranged weapons in this game are going to be a bow & arrows, or spears.

This game still plays a lot like FC 3 and 4. Same crafting and gathering system, with everything still easily marked on the map. Same stealth system, same takedown system. The biggest difference is that you aren't going to be hosing everything down with machine guns, instead you're going to actually have to aim a bow or a spear, or you can crush their skulls with a club. Good times =)

reviewText:
I disagree with all the hate.

Far Cry Primal is a great game. People say its repeatative, go here, get that, but its not. Sure you have to travel, but for different reasons. In my four hours so far, ive already saved a hunter, helped a crazed warrior burn corpses, escape a freak's cave filled with leopards and urine, gone on 3 acid trips, hunted a bear, and created a village. And you know what, I regret nothing. I havent even scratch the games surface yet, and im already having tons of fun.

Hunting is amazing. To track an animal, then hunt it down, or, even better, have my recently tamed bear wipe it out by tackling it and biting its throat. Visuals are outstanding from affar, fur gets a litle funky up close, but thats understandable.

People say the characters arent interesting because they dont speak english. I find that a lie. I have met a fearful gatherer, who wants to be more than she is, a crazed shaman who loved getting me high as the sky, a insane warrior who loved to burn corpses, and a elderly hunter who thinks i look like a mammoth. Not to mention the one armed psycho who peed on me.

I dont follow all the hate for this game, yes its not perfect, but its a long way from a thumbs down. Id rate it a personal 8.8/10 Its good, the only downfall I see, is getting my damn population count to 40. Other than that, Far Cry Primal has taken me to a time i never thought I'd see, and I wouldnt trade that for the world.

reviewText:
Well, I just finished the game, and I have to say, I think it's one of the best FarCrys yet.  The reviews so far are all over the place, and some people I normally agree with hate it, and others love it. Shoot, there's even some apathy.  I had a great time in the game, and it felt like a good length.   Maybe the game's format just wasn't what I needed at the time, but I still haven't finished FarCry 3, whereas I powered through 4 and Primal. The map feels like a great size, although I wish the snowy areas and tundra were expanded on, as well as marshier marshes and maybe some other terrain as well.  Love the sequoia style fir trees.  The game has some of the best ambient lighting I've ever seen, especially at night with the moon out and distant fires lit throughout the land casting their cozy glow.

The combat needs a tad bit of fleshing - if melee is a focus, blocking and dodging should also be options.  Swinging and powerswinging is nice, and the autoaim is enjoyable for the most part.  Even if you're not a great counterstike player, you can still nail those satifying headshots with a spear atop a sprinting sabrecat, and those are some great moments.  There is much repetition - indeed, I could save a lot of words if I simply agreed with someone else that said it was FarCry 3 with a Caveman skin, just like 4 was 3 with an alpine skin.  There's a lot of fetch and kill quests, but the characters are great and some of the dialogue you get makes the grinding seem less grindy.  The owl is a treat, and the one thing that really changed, I felt.  No longer are you restricted to binoculars. I remember a lot of speclation about what, exactly, one would climb in this game, and the answer is naught.  Cliffs, to be sure, but you actually light bonfires instead of climbing towers.  The bonfires are like small, small forts, though some of the endgame enemies (midgame?) like the yellow shield fellas with flaming clubs, can still make them a challege.  As always, and more so than ever, pulling off a stealth takeover on a fort is a feat.

In any case, I'm just rambling with no sense of focus.

TL;DR -  Is FarCry 3 with Cavemen. Beautiful atmospherics, fun quests and dialogue, but similar game.  Uncover the map 'n' kill stuff.  Very fun at base level - just running and hunting is a treat.  Fetch quests are omnipresent. Owl is great.

PS: URKI!!! He's back - only he could pull off a trailer-trash caveman that, even though speaking a primitive dialect with powerful, dignified-sounding words, still sounds like he just rolled out of a double-wide in lower Alabama.  Amazing.

reviewText: I like this game a lot, however I was a bit dissapointed on the inaccuracies and underrepresentation of the wildlife this game showed.  Oros is supposed to be a place set in Centeral Europe durning the end of the Pleistocene.   However there were a couple species that weren't found in Europe durning those times that were in the game. Such as: Tapirs, Yak, the Gray Langur Monkey, Crocodile, and the Sabertooth Tiger.\n\nI understand that Ubisoft was trying to make a more wilder world when making Far Cry Primal by adding these animals but they could of made a more dyanmic, more diverse world by adding animals that were found in Europe durning this time. Animals like: Bison, Cave Hyean, Aurochs, Musk Ox, Hippos, Horses, Barbary Macaque, and lastly Homotherium. Now if they ever add these species that would be pretty sweet. All and all a decent game.

reviewText:
This is a Far Cry game. It's an open world first person shooter (With bows and spears) set in the year 10,000 BCE. It's got collectibles, outposts to scout out and capture, and bonfires which open up the surrounding map.

By far, the biggest knock against this game is that it is ostensibly too similar to Far Cry 4. However, I never played Far Cry 4 and my last Far Cry game played was Blood Dragon in 2014. It's the proven Far Cry formula and it still works. If you're tired of it, then I suggest you wait until a sale. But, for me, it was worth the price.

Removing the guns from a Far Cry game was a bold step and I welcomed the difference. Combat is closer than the past far cry games since spears and bows don't have the range of a sniper rifle. This change made me have to adapt my usual play style to make it work. I played the game as a pseudo open world stealth game as a result. Sneaking through the night dodging wolves and bears only to chuck a freaking spear into the back of some dudes head and then watching the impact cause him to fly off a cliff was always satisfying. I'm pretty sure I killed 2 guys with the same spear once.

I spent about 40 hours with this game and never got bored with it. I didn't even do every side quest or collectible so if you're a completionist, you can dump a ton of time into this game. The setting was very interesting and the story wrapped up nicely.

Bottom line is that it's a Far Cry game. If you're new to the series, this is an interesting place to start. If you're tired of the formula then maybe wait until you see a sale. But this game isn't as bad as some have said.

reviewText: I like this game a lot, however I was a bit dissapointed on the inaccuracies and underrepresentation of the wildlife this game showed.  Oros is supposed to be a place set in Centeral Europe durning the end of the Pleistocene.   However there were a couple species that weren't found in Europe durning those times that were in the game. Such as: Tapirs, Yak, the Gray Langur Monkey, Crocodile, and the Sabertooth Tiger.\n\nI understand that Ubisoft was trying to make a more wilder world when making Far Cry Primal by adding these animals but they could of made a more dyanmic, more diverse world by adding animals that were found in Europe durning this time. Animals like: Bison, Cave Hyean, Aurochs, Musk Ox, Hippos, Horses, Barbary Macaque, and lastly Homotherium. Now if they ever add these species that would be pretty sweet. All and all a decent game.

reviewText:
- I play on an SSD, GTX 980 Ti FTW, and OC'd Intel CPU. I play on 4k resolution, ultra graphics and have had absolutely no crashes. I think the first day I played when I tried to exit it froze up on me, but nothing the task manager couldn't handle. Nothing  game breaking.

That being said; the game is fantastic. Visuals are excellent, I love the survival feel to it, I like not having a gun and having to feel a bit more like a survivor in a big dangerous world; until you get the long bow, tamed Saber and get really good at anticipating your enemy; then it's easy as pie to take down an entire village.

There are a lot of standard features seen in other Far Cry games though, in this one, so the experience of being a 'new idea' only lays within the atmosphere. Starting half of the country-side on fire, or doing simple missions for the tribes is nothing new. The standard, same, clunky climbing system and uneventful underwater encounters as we have all experienced in the past with the Far Cry series.

Same stuff, different setting; really. Graphics are slightly upgraded, runs smooth, maintains a nice frame rate for a system that can handle it. Really just a shame that it doesn't feel like a new game, just a mod of the previous releases of the game. Nonetheless I still enjoyed the experience.

Overall it's good. A change of scenery and change of pace with the weapon choices; give it a 8/10 **Here's to hoping the 2018+ version of Far Cry has some NEW ideas.

reviewText:
I've been wanting a game like this for YEARS and it's finally here. This being Far Cry, there's a lot of hand holding with the UI and mini map. People complain about the Owl, but you all know you can not use it right? This game could use the grace of mods, and normal difficulty is waaay too easy.

That said, the scenery is freaking gorgous, the setting is fresh and authentic. Hunting and being hunted by animals is unpredictiable and exciting. The characters are likeable, and I have yet to get bored. I love this game and I hope to see more games set in this prehistoric setting.

The only con is you need a more powerful processor to make the thing run with out lag. I imagine this won't be a problem for most people though...

reviewText:
First part of this review is mainly about ''errors and everything bad'' during day one.
Bought the game yesterday and preloaded. Today before work downloaded last bits of the game and went to work.
Came back from work, had lunch, made coffee and installed Nvidia Game Ready drivers (they weren't available at 6am CET)
Game loaded flawlessly. Set everything on high. Game started and so far I had great and beautiful experience in the land of Oros.
No crashes. No errors. Nothing.
Don't take those bad reviews to heart. They clearly lack the patience and understanding.

Speaking of setting and Far Cry franchise, I have to admit this is my first encounter. I've heard of the games but never had any interest in them. But game set in Stone age with a little twist of beast mastery? I just couldn't let it pass me by.

Heard melee combat is rudimentary. I really don't mind.
Heard the story is weak. So far I met only Sayla and had few of Udum and wildlife encounters. Scripted stuff is fun and gorgeous looking.
World is gorgeous, I haven't took this many screenshots dunno how long.
Will it be your cup of tea?
Can't really say but I recommend watching some videos and exploring what game offers (that's what I did)
And don't trust Steam user review score (standing at Mixed now, was Mostly negative at 6am CET)

Remember, games are about fun and for me, immersion into another world.
Far Cry Primal delivers on both.

so i was a little disappointed by the lack of survival aspect for the game

that said i still reccomend this game.

reviewText:
Genuenly surprised to see at the amount of people complaining about glitches/launch issues....
Didnt experience a single glitch or technical issue with the game, graphics are great even on my crappy medium settings.
Gameplay is the same as any other FC game but the addition of OP animals and the stress they bring is very welcomed.
My wolf killed a guy and peed on him 11/10.
All in all the game answered most of my expectations, but theres something integral missing imo :
NO CONNECTION TO THE OTHER CHARACTERS, I mean, in FC3 your guy had his douchy friends to save, denis often talked to him and Citra engaged with him. You also had a memorable enemy. In FC4 you had Sabal and Amita and several others who would engage with you, and a memorable enemy. In FCP you have NOBODY engaging with you in a more than go fetch me this/go do that for me" social way. It just feels like youre doing chores for people rather than HELP them or work WITH them. The only character so far who I have any sort of "emotional" connection with is Karoosh because so far hes the only one to express emotions towards you in a meaningful way (imo).
if you take out the nonexistant bond-forming in the game its a 7/10 hunting simulator.
if that doesnt bother you you should deff get the game. 9 hours in and the time just flew."

reviewText:
Ok here's a first review after 8h of gameplay.

I'll get right to the performances of the game that are very good in my opinion. I run the game at 1440p in Ultra and rarely drops below 50fps. Most of the time I'm at a steady 60fps. My rig is quite powerful (i7 4790, 16gb RAM, Gtx 980ti and a G-sync screen) but I've seen some alarming post from people playing with equal or better rigs having crappy performances so I kinda wonder what's the deal here.

Gameplay: well, it's Far Cry with all the good things and bad things that goes with the licence. There's barely anything new here (appart from the Taming) but to be honest, It doesn't bother me as I knew what I was signing for here. Anyone pretending otherwise must live in a cave without internet. The game is more brutal than 3 & 4, lot more punishing early on but once you get the hang of things and your new tools, ennemies (humans and beast) are kinda easy to dispatch. Special mention for the first Izila fort captain who gave me some trouble (I wwasn't prepared!)

Graphics & Atmosphere: as I said, I play on ultra @1440p and its gorgeous. Once again, not many improvements from 3 & 4 but everything looks fantastic. Some textures are still low quality but hey... No nvidia crap" this time
date: that should make AMD users happy. Furs and beards still looks cool though.\n\nOverall the atmosphere is very good with smooth day/night transition and lights effects are well adjusted (to my taste at least!). I've noticed some discrepencies somehow from objects that shouldn't be in this era and some subtitles using words that couldn't have existed at the time but that's just me being a nerd I think. The langage invented for the occasion seems rich and credible
recommended: and is very well interpreted by the voice actors.\n\nMusic and sounds: nothing much to say about it

reviewText: All of the negative reviews I've seen so far complain about two things. Number one, that having windows firewall enabled stops the game from opening. Number two, that the framerate is bad and makes the game choppy and hard to play. So how can the everyman PC gamer avoid these two problems? Start by turning off windows firewall. That should take about two seconds. Secondly, if your PC doesnt have the hardware to hang with a brand new massive open world open RPG, dont get mad when you cant run it at 60 FPS on Ultra graphics. I'm running the game on Ultra and having no issues. My framerate consistently stays above 50 and the game looks beautiful. In addition, I'm having a lot of fun with it. Don't let people who don't know how to use their computer detract you from buying and playing Far Cry Primal.

reviewText:
I want to start off by expressing utter shock and disbelief over all the negative reviews this game has recieved, and for the content of them all...

Let me warn you now. This is a FARCRY game, so if you want to hunt, utilize stealth, control animals, take outposts etc. This is the still the game for you, UNLESS, you are one of these children that can't stand a game a truly and beautifully immersive game.

After just 5-6 hours of gameplay I am trying not to sit down and play right now, my village needs me...
There's no other game (Amnesa, Slender) That matches this game in fear. I've screamed at the top of my lungs in fear, anger, rage and then fear again, all in five hours of playing this game. And I ♥♥♥♥ing loved it.

Also, this game is set in 10,000 BCE, if you're expecting harpoon guns and throwing daggers you need to learn what that means.

I'm very impressed with the overall sound quality of this game. I use a Razer Tiamat 7.1 and the effects in the game don't take too long to take me out of my world and into theirs, everything about this game is incredibly immersive but they really nailed the audio effects, I'm not gonna lie, bricks were ♥♥♥♥ when I heard a jaguar up coming behind me.

My personal favorite part of this game is the (Spoilers) Village of people you have to help and manage grow. You start out basically alone and through bringing food, wood, supplies etc to a village you will attract other remnants of your society to reside with you in the village, this made the immersion incredibly more real to me because I really did care for these people and what happened to them, because, in a time and place like that; we were all we had, and it really felt like that too.

Animals:
I haven't got far into this part of the game yet, I've only tamed my 2nd wolf (♥♥♥♥ing love him) but I feel as though they should keep on adding more animals into the game as time progresses, along with tools, to keep the game interesting for years to come

reviewText: This game is unique in its own way. Im finding it extremely fun wandering through prehestoric plains, mountains and forests and hunting large beasts. I knowe alot of people are complaining about the game crashing but I have a medium to high end PC and have never experience any crashes,glitches, bugs, or catches as of yet. Also you may have heard the map uses the same shape as the previous game only redone and has a different look........yea so? Does that make it not fun? Its been smooth sailing and tons of fun for me so far. Im glad they went a different route with this game and didnt make another modern day Farcry shooter as we have already had 4 of those. If you like large land masses, different biomes, different dangerous tribes, taming a massive cave bear only to send him to eat a caveman, and a large collection and variety of prehistoric beasts and killing said beasts with primitive weapons then this game is for you. Would recommend the buy!

I have not played any other Far Cry games, let me state this first.

The game was fun, it was intersting to 'go back in time' and play in such a manor. The game does reward stealth so it does not need to just be a spear everything and just spam. The animals do add to the game and some are fun to have along. You can reset some of the objectives and start 'over' again, which does give it a limited replay ability.

Now, for the parts I don't like. You can learn all skills, so at one point there is no reason to earn EXP, your Takkar will be just like everyone elses in the end. (I know this isnt an RPG, but still.) It is an extremly short game in my opinion. I have 100% in game, not all achevments though. Melee combat is a bit rough, so I mostly used bows or spears. Owl bombing run will clear an encampment way to easly. Again this is fixed by not using it, again, just an obsevation. Something that maybe an ongoing thing in FarCry games that I dont know about is Urki. He just didnt fit in the setting. I will admit he was funny, just seemed out of place.

All in all i do recomend this game. I dont think its worth $60 for the limited game play though. It ended up being about a dollor and hour.

reviewText:
Coming back to write my in-depth review.

*There are not any Spoilers that I know of, but just in case here is a little Caution: Potential Spoilers*

[TL:DR] - The scenery is beautiful, and nothing anyone will regret looking at. This s the perfect stone-age open world game. The graphics are fantastic, the gameplay is suitable, and the glitches (for me) are minor to none. I highly recommend this game. Also, I wish we could name our pets!

I will start off by saying I've contributed a lot of time with the game so far, and will definitely continue too. This game has gotten a lot of crap and negativity from people anywhere from pre-ordering down to the nature of the game.

Scenery: I have to say I am impressed. The scenes in this game are absolutely breathtaking and screenshot-worthy at almost every frame. I would have bought this game simply to take in the world. It has been constructed incredibly well and lacks in no areas. You can tell a lot of effort has been put into the making of this world. From the foliage and ambiance, down to the trickles of water, the nature and sound completely immerse you within' a new era.

Sound: The sound is authentic. You can hear screams in the distance, animals, enemies, and birds. Each step you take, and arrow you are about to fire come accompanied with an absolute quality of sound where I have no complaints. The sound in this game truly brings to life the atmosphere and ties in well with the world's reactions.

Gameplay: The characters do not feel stiff to me, and look fluid and natural within' their actions. I am slightly saddened by the effects and actions of portions of the game, however. I do not like that when I stab an enemy or an animal, there are no marks. It truly pulls me back into the realization that I'm not submersed within' the world. I wish that it was done better. Needless to say, a lot of other aspects of the game make up for it. And not to mention, having your own pets fight for you? That's awesome! The quests keep coming up, and the side-quests are endless. I really enjoy this feature as I do not feel bored. I am overwhelmed with things to do, which is a good thing! Nobody likes a boring game!

Skills/beasts/weapons: As far as skills go, I do enjoy the way they've been constructed. I like that you need to unlock different Wenja in order to obtain their skill trees. I think this is a very good feature, and also, there are a ton of skills! I adore beast taming. I wish that I could name each of my beasts! That would be extremely cool, and hopefully they will find a way to implement it in the future.  Fingers crossed! You can tame a variety of beasts, and using your skill points, you can unlock the tames of other, stronger beasts. As far as weapons go, the selection is numbered. While being low in diversity, I didn't really mind. I like that the weapons are basic, you have your bow, your club, and your spear. What more do you really need in the stone age anyway? I think they chose very good weapons, and their limit was fine. I also love that you can upgrade your weapons. Your bow can be turned into a longbow, and a double-arrowed bow, for example.

So what?: This game has a lot to offer, and I haven't seen many games of it's type. The Era, being the stone age, is such an awesome idea. An open world game set in the stone age is something that really drawed me into want to purchase the game. I also appreciate the pricing, a lot of Steam games (due to coming with season passes) are up in the $100 dollar range, so it was nice to be able to purchase a game of such a high quality and not have to spend the almost $40-$50 extra (USD). For the price, I think the game is perfectly fine and I highly recommend it.

Glitches/problems/etc: As per my own experience, I have not had any frame-rate issues, nor frozen screens. The game runs perfectly fine for me, and need I say it runs flawless. I had 1 glitch throughout my time, and it was quite minor. The glitch I experienced was by a lake, I seemed to have fell through the map when I crouched, and instead of falling to my inevitable death, I was put in water. The way the area was built, water must have flown not only from the depth of the river, but also under the land, so it was pretty much there to catch my fall. I swam back over to the river and voila! I was fine.

My Rating Scoreboard:

[] Trash
[] Do not buy
[] Maybe… but only maybe
[] If you’re into this kind of thing
[] Only purchase when on sale
[] You won’t regret it!
[x]  Well done! Worth the money!


-Thank you for reading!

reviewText: Most negative reviews on here thus far seem to focus on startup errors and crashes. I haven't experienced any crashes, glitches, or errors yet- thankfully. I'm only about 2 hours into Primal, but I'm finding it very enjoyable. The mechanics aren't deep, but Ubi nailed the atmospere.\nPrimal is immersive and intense. Hand-to-hand combat is quick, viscious, and brutal. Bows and spears function well, and having to constantly hunt in order to heal seems very fitting to the period. Being only 2 hours into the game, I've barely made it out of the prologue, so I can't comment on story as yet.\nBut so far so good. This game gets the peroid feel down, and I have to hand it to a corporate publisher like Ubi to allow their team the creative freedom they obviously needed for this game. I'll update this review as needed, but I am very much enjoying this game. That hinges on appreciating it for what it is- escapist FPS with a unique setting. Far Cry games aren't the Cohen brothers and Fargo. They're Michael Mann and Heat, and that's perfectly fine.

reviewText:
I had a preload and everything worked fine on the premiere yesterday. Only thing I had to do was to add it to Avast exclusions. The game runs smoothly on very high settings on my medium range PC. I have a stable rate of 55-60 fps (and I’m tempted to try it on ultra). Graphics are very nice (granted, it’s not Rise of Tomb Raider level of awesomeness), the wildlife and the forest look terrific (albeit the waterfalls are terrible). The soundtrack fits the game perfectly and the ambient is superb. It’s a very atmospheric game, especially when you hunt at night.

For me the story is fun. It’s pretty much what I was expecting from a story about a primitive tribe. Ubisoft’s crafted language is simply awesome. And it’s not gibberish, as some might think. They actually tried to make it from scratch (apparently from Proto-Indo-European. It’s pretty easy to pick up familiar sounding words (like tiger – tigri or brother – brashtar).

Gameplay is good – but it’s my very first Far Cry game ever. Previous titles never grasped me as particularly interesting. I’m not a great fan of FPS games. But Far Cry Primal, as an action game, is good enough for me. I’m happy Ubisoft decided to change the setting to 10k BC, because otherwise I’d probably never pick a Far Cry game at all (and now I’m a little bit tempted to try other parts of the series, maybe).

The only gripe for me is the overall number of animals. I want more of them (hint for Ubisoft – make a DLC!). I’d love to see aurochs, giganthopitecus, primal horses (yes, there were horses back then as well) and some more extinct exotic mammals, like gomphotheres.

I don’t mind that there are only a few weapons, but it would be nice if they could add a sling and maybe an atlatl or a bolas. Other than that, one or two more tribesman with missions wouldn’t hurt.

Overall I’m pretty satisfied with this game.

reviewText:
One word. Boring.
This will be the last Far Cry game I ever purchase and I have them all except FC1.

The world of Far Cry is way too easy in 2016, and that's exactly what this game is. This is just the previous Far Cry games in ancient times with ancient tools. They put a lot of work into the ancient setting, but not much on making the game fun. Games shouls have an iterative fun" development cycle much like Pillars of Eternity demonstrated in their dev diary's.

Even turning off all of the Interface Elements

reviewText:
This is not your average Far Cry game. If you go in expecting another Far Cry with different mechanics, or improved combat, this may not be the game for you.
If you want to experience a creative take on prehistoric life with gritty combat and everything out to kill you, then this is your game!
The pet system along with the primitive aspect of your abilities and weapons makes this a game about hunting prey. It's not stalking: steath is only so-so in Primal, but what it does do well is communicate a sense of hunting prey down to become an apex predator yourself. I found the immersive culture, visuals, and time period to be the greatest part of the game. I enjoyed playing through it and yes it is short compared to other Far Cry games, but I think it has more replayability. I loved the sense of total vulnerability from the beginning of the game, and evolving into a nonchalant badass by the end-game. Note: my favorite games arent FPS's, I enjoy them but don't adore them.

If you want something new, creative, and interesting to throw your time into then pick it up. If you want a copy/paste Far Cry experience, replay an old one.

8/10 - It's good, but Far Cry is just in the title; it's its own game.

reviewText:
I don't know why all of these people seem to be having issues, but I would like to share my input, since I will seemingly be the only recent person with a Yes on the recommendation due to actually being able to play it.

Being able to absolutely customize the controls per my gaming mouse (Naga Epic) is absolutely fantastic.
The graphics are solid.
The combat is fluid and honestly terrifying at certain points on the harder difficulties.
Being able to dive bomb the enemies to allow for more stealth related camp takes is amazing.
I personally prefer the Jaguar for stealth and Brown Bear for pure force so far, while using the White Wolf to travel.
The sheer terror of a competent AI (in most situations) is something I love in a game.
The fact that enemy archers can shoot you while zig zagging kind of sucks, but it makes it more challenging :D
The bombs and traps are fantastic and ridiculously fun to use.
Taming can be a bit of a pain until you get the hang of it.

The worst thing in the world is making a tactical retreat from about 10 enemies only to get mauled by a leopard. lol

Honestly I'm finding it hard to find much of anything wrong with the game. The anti-stealth tactics are somewhat a little too skyrim like in the fact that I feel like they could care less when their friends get an arrow to the face, but other than that, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game so far. Fantastic job.

reviewText:
If you are a long time Far Cry player hoping for some fresh air, your experiences may vary. This review is for those who find the premise interesting but have only occassionally played other Far Cry games if at all.

-Very pretty game. You'll feel like you've been outdoors.

-The human mind is shaped by hundreds of thousands of years of living this way, and therefore there's a deep level of satisfaction simulating it. You are meant to thrive in an environment like this one.
-- The savage triumph of throwing a burning spear through the head of your foe while dodging his arrow.
-- The splendor of the forest seeps into your heart, warming you with the rays of sunset, when the single cry of a nearby bear shatters it with sheer panic.
-- A pack of wolves circles you in the moonlight, glowing eyes piercing the shadows. But you are the danger.


-Makes you think ... your RL doesn't suck so much. People really really lived like this. I haven't had one mammoth trample me IRL today.

-The fantasy elements (beast taming, etc) are also very well done, doesn't even nudge the suspension of disbelief.

Recommend playing on expert difficulty for best experience.

reviewText:
One word. Boring.
This will be the last Far Cry game I ever purchase and I have them all except FC1.

The world of Far Cry is way too easy in 2016, and that's exactly what this game is. This is just the previous Far Cry games in ancient times with ancient tools. They put a lot of work into the ancient setting, but not much on making the game fun. Games shouls have an iterative fun" development cycle much like Pillars of Eternity demonstrated in their dev diary's.

reviewText:
I have 8gb ram (if you have less, you will not play this game), and old 1gm gtx 660( and it looks pretty good on normal settings) AMD 8310 8-core 3.4 processor.
Yes it is kinda a reskin, of Farcry 3 and 4.But to me that's a selling point. I don't like FPS with guns( yeah I know how that sounds).
The taming of animal's having your owl kill everyone guarding a bon-fire, makes up for it in my book.
We all know Ubisoft has never been great on costumer service, getting the game to run on everyone's Pc seems to be an after thought. Always has been.
Not sure if I'd say it's worth 60 bucks. But rarely do I ever pay that much, most the time I wait for it to go on sale in a few months MAYBE some of the issues others have been having, or MAYBE the game developers will pull their heads out they ♥♥♥♥, and find out what's causing this so called error ( I;m not getting it)
If you're not sure if you may like it. If you are on the fence about it, watch some live broadcasts and make an informed decision.

reviewText: So I guess they fixes a lot of the problems other people were having, that i saw in a lot of the negative reviews.  I have had no issues at all so far.  It started right up.  Just got through the intro did a mission, discovered a few places.  Killed a jaguar, cave lion and a bunch of other peeps.  So far i really like the game. I have nothing negative to say.  Ultra graphics look fantastic on 2k. If you like far cry i am pretty sure you will like this game too.

reviewText:
I tamed an owl, I named him Simon. Simon crashed into a cliff and died. I tried to give him CPR but a tiger came and ate me. The End.

Update: I have found a friendly sabertooth tiger and adopted him as my own. I named him Sebastion and we roam around the woods killing everything and picking berries.


In all seriousness, don't get this game if you are hoping it's Far Cry, besides a few similar thing there is almost nothing in common with the other games. The graphics are amazingly good, some of the scenery is just awesome. The content seems to be lacking too much depth. I have always enjoyed Far Cry's well scripted cut scenes and this game does not deliver that as well as in the past. I have had no problems with my game glitching or not starting correctly and I am basically a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ so, I'm not sure what those other people did with their versions of the game.
voteText: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I don't know why all of these people seem to be having issues, but I would like to share my input, since I will seemingly be the only recent person with a Yes on the recommendation due to actually being able to play it.

Being able to absolutely customize the controls per my gaming mouse (Naga Epic) is absolutely fantastic.
The graphics are solid.
The combat is fluid and honestly terrifying at certain points on the harder difficulties.
Being able to dive bomb the enemies to allow for more stealth related camp takes is amazing.
I personally prefer the Jaguar for stealth and Brown Bear for pure force so far, while using the White Wolf to travel.
The sheer terror of a competent AI (in most situations) is something I love in a game.
The fact that enemy archers can shoot you while zig zagging kind of sucks, but it makes it more challenging :D
The bombs and traps are fantastic and ridiculously fun to use.
Taming can be a bit of a pain until you get the hang of it.

The worst thing in the world is making a tactical retreat from about 10 enemies only to get mauled by a leopard. lol

Honestly I'm finding it hard to find much of anything wrong with the game. The anti-stealth tactics are somewhat a little too skyrim like in the fact that I feel like they could care less when their friends get an arrow to the face, but other than that, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game so far. Fantastic job.
voteText: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I haven't played Farcry 4, so I'm sure that is influencing my opinion. Having said that, this game is great. I run around and do caveman things in a caveman world. Beat up neanderthals and take their stuff. Rescue other cavemen and women and get them to join my tribe.

The world looks pretty good. It seems to be at that perfect point where it will run good on a majority of PC's and still looks nice when you jack the settings up.

I had no issues getting the game to work. A lot of people seem to be complaining about this. Well it's not the developers fault you have software or a firewall that prevents the game from connecting to their servers. This is the world we live in now. DRM is the game talking to the developers servers. Get used it and learn to configure your ♥♥♥♥ properly.

reviewText: I didn't like the way the other Far Cry games look - I'm a bow and arrows sort of gal. And you know what? I love this game. There is nothing sweeter than sending your beast in to kill things for you while you throw spears and shoot from a distance. I just wish there were more skills and more things to upgrade.\n\nAlso, has a pretty interesting story in my opinion which is a bit surprising given the nature of the game. I love it. Wish I could have played as a character other than Takkar afterwards, like unlocking one of the female characters to play first person as. Or even playing as one of the other groups (Sun Warriors (Izila?) or the Udam). But this game just came out. There's time for improvement.

reviewText: Far Cry Primal is the next game in the Far Cry series. It shies away from the previous games in the series that were mostly set in a more modern setting, and instead introduces the player to what life was like in the Far Cry universe 10,000 years before the common era. You play as Takkar and belong to the tribe known as the Wenja, which you figure out very early into the game are the punching bags of the two other dominant tribes occupying Oros... and also the animals occupying the inhospitable region. Frankly the Wenja are terrible at surviving, which is where you come in! In your epic caveman quest to become the baddest creature in Oros you will need to take on animals and humans alike by crafting better weapons, taking advantage of native plants to help adapt to new situations, and tame some of the fierce animals that inhabit Oros itself to aid you in pushing back the Wenja tribe's aggressive neighbors.\n\nIf you enjoyed the solid game mechanics from Far Cry 4 you will welcome their understandable return. Sprinting across Oros while hunting man or animal feels fluid, and once you invest some points into Takkar's caveman perk tree of... caveman skills, you will come to find sneaking, scavenging, and combat becoming much easier. There is even a simle village growth" aspect to the game; the more Wenja you rescue from danger and the more unique characters you bring into the fold
date: the more the village grows. You won't have a direct influence on the growth
recommended: but it is satisfying seeing the area become full of people who can't survive on their own.\n\nThe story itself is regrttably short
hoursPlayed: but the gameplay itself more than makes up for it. If you are a completionist than the sheer amounts of quests for you to complete will be an encouragement in and of itself
voteText: even if they can become repetitive. Upgrading your gear and taming beasts is very entertaining
helpfulPercent: and I would recommend doing as much as possible early on to help you feel more like an Apex predator once the time comes for you to take on the other two tribes in their respective questlines."

reviewText:
Not a bad game its like most far cry games just no guns or vehicles. Its got Resource gathering, a lot of crafting, base/village building, animals to kill, bad guys to kill, and so on and so forth.

This game is getting a lot of hate and most of it is people just being trolls. I have seen people complaining about the lack of guns and vehicles and all I have to say about that is don't buy the game that's set in 10,000 bc were bows and spears were high-tech if you want guns.

The complains about optimization and what not are trash to its not the game its your computer I have played this on my laptop and got 60 fps on max settings no problem  so its not the game its the users pc.

The only real complaints that are worth anything are the ones about error messages and what not but stuff like that is going to happen after the launch of a game there are just to many different configurations of pcs out there for them to make sure a game will work on them all.
